It tastes the rain and scoffs at streams,
Devours whole the wooden dreams
Of ships and homes. Yet in its wrath,
Renews the soil on nature's path.

We court this lover, fierce and grand,
With pyres lit by trembling hand,
For in its light we see revealed
What darkness kept so long concealed.

Fire: Not beast nor god but something strange,
That thrives on air and loves to change
Its shape—a serpent, then a spire,
Then ghostly smoke that climbs up higher.

It cooks the meat, it melts the ore,
It cauterizes wounds of war.
It signals tribes across the moor,
A language older than folklore.

Beware its kiss upon the skin,
That turns the living man within
To charcoal. Yet without its spark,
We'd grope in dark, eternal dark.

So praise this fickle deity,
Both life and death's bright battery—
A stolen fragment of the sun,
Contained until its race is run.

Fire: Wild child of friction's sudden scream,
The nightmare trapped within a dream
Of warmth. See how it paints the walls
With shifting, predatory squalls!

It licks the log with golden glee,
Then sighs to ash reluctantly.
In lanterns, guards against the deep;
In forests, lays the giants asleep.

We worship at its altar stones,
While fearing what the wind intones
When sparks take flight like frantic birds—
The final, all-consuming words.

O elemental paradox!
Our servant and our savage fox.
You forge our progress, scar our earth...
The cost of every human birth.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs.'

text.response:
The iron beast exhales its steamy sigh,
A whistle pierces the still-dreaming sky.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
As wheels on tracks begin to bite and sting her
Sleepy silence. Commuters press their faces
To foggy glass where dawn's first light erases
Night's charcoal sketches. Briefcases tap restless feet
While station ghosts retreat in slow defeat.
A thousand stories board in rusted cars -
The student clutching textbooks to her stars,
The salesman smoothing worries like his tie,
The child tracing rain-streaks sliding by.
Each window frames a moving watercolor:
Mist-kissed fields replace the urban squalor.
The rhythm builds - a metallic lullaby
That stitches towns where waking rooftops lie.
This transient chapel hums with expectation,
A shared suspension toward new destinations,
As power lines dip low in reverent bows
To fleeting temples on these rolling vows.

Dawn's pale fingers pry apart the dark
When steel-on-steel ignites the station's spark.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
Like perfume from a stranger's restless finger
Tracing schedules. Whispers build and twine
With coffee steam and platform's yellow line.
The shudder runs through concrete, bone and case -
A shared heartbeat accelerates its pace.
Doors sigh open - mouths of hungry steel -
Swallowing commuters' morning zeal.
Then comes the lurch, that sweet gravitational pull
Where gravity and freedom beautifully mull
Their contract. Telegraph poles begin their dance,
Flickering past in trance-like circumstance.
The city sheds its skin in brick and mortar
As countryside unfolds like some grand porter
Revealing parcels of dew-drenched green
Where yesterday's rain makes the pastures gleam.
This carriage holds a hundred separate yearnings
Set to the clack of iron wheels' returning
Chant.

A cough. A rustle. Platform's nervous hum.
The 6:15 has yet to come.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
In jittery feet that tap like a trigger
Ready. Then brakes scream - a wounded creature -
And doors unfold their aluminum features.
The migration begins: briefcases, backpacks,
Newspapers rustling, zippers, knapsacks
Jostling. Then the lurch! The great exhale!
As station pillars begin to thin and pale
Behind us. Now the windows paint a river
Of blurring streets that shiver and quiver
With motion. Sunlight bleeds across the aisle,
Gilding drowsy faces mile by mile.
This is the alchemy of transit's art:
Strangers sharing oxygen and heartbeats,
Watching factories yawn as they depart
Their smokestack dreams. The rhythm never ceases -
Clickety-clack like fortune-teller's bones -
As through tunnel's throat the carriage moans
Then bursts into the green-gold countryside
Where mist still pools in valleys, soft and wide.

Steam rises ghostly in the station's chill
As travelers cluster, tense and strangely still.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
In silent glances. Then a metallic finger
Points down the track. A murmur swells and spreads
Like rustling leaves. The engine nods its head
And groans. Doors hiss - a decompressing sigh -
Inviting chaos in. The human river flows by
In suits and scarves. The shudder through the floor
Becomes a pulse behind each closing door.
Then movement! Buildings slide like fallen blocks
Behind accelerating windows. Someone unlocks
Their thermos - coffee scent now fills the air
As suburbs streak beyond the window's square.
This is the liminal space, the rolling threshold
Where daydreams outpace worries tenfold.
The conductor's call becomes a lulling chant
As bridges cross the rivers' sleepy slant.
We're time-travelers in this rattling capsule,
Watching night's residue become morning's example
Of light reborn. Each passenger contains
A universe the journey entertains
And rearranges.

The platform clock's heartbeat ticks too slow,
Anticipation swells in every toe
That taps. You can hear the excitement start to linger
As brakes release their groan. The diesel singer
Clears its throat. Then movement - first a creep,
Then gathering speed where shadows stretch and leap
Beside us. Telegraph wires dip and rise
Like staves where sparrows jot musical skies.
The city sheds its concrete overcoat,
Revealing pastures where the morning floats
In silver puddles. Barns stand sentinel
As hills begin their slow, majestic swell.
This carriage breathes a hundred different airs -
Perfume, newsprint, someone's apple shares -
While wheels compose their ceaseless click-clack rhyme
Marking the passage of both space and time.
Commuters weave their silent narratives:
The woman tracing where the river lives
On wrinkled maps, the student memorizing
French verbs, the old man silently revising
His life's mistakes. We're pilgrims without shrines
Riding the rails like metallic vines
Connecting destinations yet unknown
To seeds of journey freshly sown.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs.'

text.response:
The whistle shrieks, a silver serpent slides,
From slumbered stations, dawn's first blush confides.
A clatter builds on tracks of iron spine,
As sleepy towns to waking rhythms bind.
You sense it there, a thrumming in the air,
Not just the wheels, but dreams beyond compare.
Briefcases snap with futures tightly packed,
Backpacks hold mountains where new trails contract.
A child's nose pressed to the foggy glass,
Watches the world become a blurring mass.
Lovers entwined, their whispered hopes take flight,
While commuters calculate the coming light.
That hum grows deep where steel and concrete meet,
A pulsing promise down the urban street.
It lingers long after the carriage fades,
In coffee steam and bustling promenades.
The city stirs, a beast of many parts,
Ignited by departure's vibrant arts.

Perched on the platform edge, the moment swells,
A symphony of sighs and farewell bells.
The engine groans, a beast of steam and might,
Unfurling clouds that swallow morning's light.
That tingling charge? Not just electric rails,
But human hearts breaching their mortal veils.
Grandmas wave hankies soaked in lavender,
Students chase adventures they'll remember.
The businessman checks watches, taut and keen,
The artist sketches worlds he's never seen.
The air itself seems thick with untold tales—
Of reunions, losses, hope that never fails.
Long after echoes fade in tunnel's gloom,
That buzz remains within the station's womb.
It seeps through tiles, up stairwells, out to streets,
Where pigeons scatter near the taxi fleets.
The city breathes the residue of starts,
Forever changed by fleeting, steel-born hearts.

First light still licks the rooftops, cold and thin,
When iron dragons wake with rumbling din.
The station yawns—a cathedral of haste,
Where time compresses, minutes go to waste.
But hark! That tremor shaking concrete floors
Is more than physics—it's what life restores.
A vibration felt in molars, in the breast,
The thrill of movement putting doubt to test.
Watch faces turn—a mosaic of intent,
Each passenger a universe half-spent
Yet crackling now with possibilities
Like static sparks from ancient deities.
The whistle screams; the platform holds its breath.
What alchemy survives this simulated death?
The train recedes. But in the coffee stall,
The baker's hands, the clerk who takes a call—
All vibrate with the residue of power
From that brief, brilliant, locomotive hour.

Steel kisses steel in shrill announcement made,
As shadows stretch in hesitant parade.
The carriage lurches—suddenly alive!
A hundred stories in the thrust and drive.
That buzz you feel isn't just piston steam,
It's longing woven into morning's dream.
The immigrant clutching photographs gone creased,
The soldier home, his inner wars not ceased.
The runaway with courage thin as thread,
The widow visiting her silent dead.
All carry futures lighter than their bags
As sunlight glints on rivets, bolts, and flags.
The station shrinks; the city starts to bloom.
But in the vacuum of the emptied room,
Where ticket stubs drift like confetti ghosts,
Excitement lingers near the waiting posts.
It soaks the benches, warms the tiled expanse—
The afterglow of destiny's swift dance.
Commute-bound crowds absorb it through their shoes,
That wild, departing, ever-chosen muse.

Dew still clings to rails like frozen tears,
When the behemoth grumbles, shakes off years
Of nighttime stillness. Hear that gathering roar?
Not just machinery—it's something more.
It's pencils poised above blank journals' pages,
It's farmers heading back to drought-struck acres,
It's interns trembling in their stiff new suits,
And musicians lugging battered, faithful flutes.
The coupling clangs; the great beast starts to glide.
What quantum shift occurs there, deep inside
The station's bones? A crackling energy
That lifts the pigeons in a frantic spree.
You taste it then—like ozone, sharp and bright—
As futures detach from the present's tight
Embrace. The platform empties, stark and bare,
But phantom laughter hangs suspended there.
Long after steel has vanished round the bend,
That spark remains where journeys start and end—
A spectral pulse in every paving stone,
Proof we're not creatures bound by flesh alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs.'

text.response:
The whistle wails, a piercing note,
awakening dreams in every throat.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
as wheels grind on cold steel finger.
Commuters clutch their steaming cups,
while dawn still licks the platform's ups.
A suitcase rolls with hurried beat,
a child points at conductor's seat.
The engine groans, a giant roused,
steam-kissed windows, dreams espoused.
Through tunnels carved in granite deep,
promises the city will soon keep.
A student scans her dog-eared page,
an artist sketches in his cage
of moving light and shifting shade,
while business deals are being made
over phones that glow like captive stars.
The rhythm writes its memoirs
in clack-clack code on iron tracks -
each station passed, a world contracts
then blooms anew in foreign lands
where strangers wave with work-worn hands.
The journey breathes, expands, contracts,
carrying futures in its sacks
of woven time and borrowed space -
this rolling, waking, human grace.

Platform sighs release their ghosts
as pistons punch their metal boasts.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
in the clatter of a dropped coat zipper.
Briefcase warriors adjust their ties,
watching sleep retreat from sky's
gray eyelids. Whispers build like steam -
reunion plans, a lover's dream
of coastal towns where waves applaud
this exodus from concrete quad.
A saxophonist tests his reed,
planting jazz in morning's seed.
The carriage lurches - sudden sway -
connecting lives in disarray.
Through brick canyons, past graffiti scars,
we tunnel under prison bars
of routine. Telegraph poles
become piano keys for souls
to play their silent overtures.
Each crossing gate, a pause that lures
adventure from suburban lawns.
The train exhales its traveler yawns
past factories stretching iron bones -
this mobile village of unknowns
stitching dawn with transient thread,
cradling hope like freshly baked bread.

Iron dragon stirs from steel cocoon,
scattering pigeons beneath the moon's
urreticent retreat. You can hear
the excitement start to linger near
the ticket booth where change still clinks
like tiny anchors. Memory winks
from windows framing hurried waves -
mothers, sons, the bold and brave.
A poet licks his pencil tip,
capturing the platform's script:
'Farewells tattooed on misty air,
backpacks stuffed with anywhere.'
The whistle shreds the station's hum,
journeys yet to be begun
unfold like origami maps.
Wheels bite tracks with hungry snaps.
Past sleeping houses, gardens trim,
where single lights defiant gleam.
The rhythm writes its geography
across the land's vast diary -
bridges scribble river names,
tunnels swallow yesterday's claims.
Each passenger becomes a verse
in motion's universal curse
and blessing. Destination's call
makes station ghosts of one and all
until return. The rails extend -
both means and message, foe and friend.

Dawn's pale fingers pry apart
the heavy velvet curtain. Start!
You can hear the excitement start to linger
in the rustle of a newspaper's finger
turning pages. Perfume drifts
from scarves as seating subtly shifts.
A vendor's trolley squeaks protest
carrying caffeine to the stressed.
The coupling clangs - metallic kiss -
commencement of the day's first waltz.
Through window frames, the world's rewound:
backyards where laundry spins around
like prayer flags. A lone bike leans
against a shed. What morning means
to different lives flashes by -
a woman hanging clouds to dry,
a baker's neon sign still bleeding light.
The tracks are taut, the journey right
as compass needles. Overpasses
throw brief shadows like molasses
on commuters. City's edge
approaches where wild violets pledge
spring's return. The rhythm speaks
in Morse code tapped by iron beaks
against the rails. Each passing mile
unfurls a temporary aisle
through ordinary mysteries -
the train, a moving gallery
of human cargo, hopes, and fears -
all carried by the engineer's
urelenting forward glance.

Station clock swallows minutes whole
as tension builds within the soul
of waiting. You can hear the start
of excitement lingering apart
from reason. Brakes exhale their steam -
a dragon waking from its dream.
The doors hiss shut like fortune's sigh.
Platform recedes. Now we fly
on land-bound wings. A toddler's gasp
as power lines perform their clasp
and release dance. Coffee swirls
in paper cups as landscape whirls
past frames: graffiti-crusted walls,
forgotten lots where ivy crawls
over rusted dreams. The rhythm grows
a heartbeat underfoot that knows
no hesitation. Telephone wires
scribble notes like broken lyres
against the clouds. Each crossing bell
rings impermanence. Farewell,
farewell to stations of the past -
this forward motion holds us fast
in present tense. The rails become
a silver thread, a pendulum
swinging between here and there.
The journey is the only prayer
we carry. Fields surrender borders
as the train, life's faithful orderer,
propels us through the morning's veil -
both destination and travail.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs.'

text.response:
The whistle pierces dawn's soft veil, a stirring in the air.
You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs.
Steel wheels kiss the tracks, humming promises of distant streets
where city lights still dance in puddles from last night's rain.
Commuters press against cold glass, breath fogging windows
as sleepy towns blur into watercolor dreams.
A child points at grazing deer, wonder bright in wide eyes
while businessmen unfold newspapers like origami cranes.
The rhythm builds—click-clack, click-clack—a heartbeat
syncopated with coffee sips and rustling pastry bags.
Hope hangs thick as steam: reunions, job interviews,
first dates penciled in worn planners.
Platform ghosts wave handkerchiefs of mist,
and we're all hurtling toward second chances
with suitcases full of maybes.

Mist clings to the platform like unfinished goodbyes.
You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs.
It carries more than passengers—it hauls daydreams
in cargo cars: a painter's Paris fantasy,
a widow's coastal escape, a student's borrowed textbooks
heavy with ambition. The conductor's call
unspools a ribbon of anticipation down the aisle.
Strangers become confidantes in shared sunrise glances,
passing thermos coffee like sacred communion.
Track vibrations resonate in ribcages as countryside
unfolds—a living tapestry of cornfield gold
and river-quicksilver. Somewhere ahead, a lover waits
with daisies bought from a street vendor.
The train isn't moving away; it's pulling tomorrow
closer with every rotating wheel.

Dew diamonds on iron rails catch the first light.
You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs—
a symphony of hissing pistons and slamming doors,
percussion for the overture of day.
Station benches hold echoes of midnight conversations
while pigeons scavenge croissant crumbs like urban archaeologists.
A musician tunes his guitar case, humming a melody
that braids with the engine's growl into something new.
The air thrums with potential: the scent of ink
from unopened love letters, the crispness of maps
folded in back pockets. Each passenger a novel
with dog-eared chapters. We are all transient,
stitching our stories between departures and arrivals
as the world blurs past—a Monet in motion.

Platform 3 breathes frost into the charcoal dawn.
You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs,
carrying fragments of reality suspended between destinations.
A dancer checks her reflection, rehearsing steps
for an audition that could change everything.
An immigrant clasps visa papers like a rosary.
Even the beggar by the newsstand dreams
of coastal trains where salt spray licks the windows.
The locomotive groans—a waking dragon—
scattering starlings from power lines into inkblot skies.
Ticket stubs become holy relics in this cathedral
of transience. We are time travelers hurtling
through tunnels where yesterday dissolves
and tomorrow hasn't yet taken shape. Only now exists:
steel, steam, and the collective gasp
as the station shrinks behind us.

First light gilds the baggage carts' metal ribs.
You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs—
a crescendo of rolling suitcases and slamming bins,
boarding passes fluttering like trapped sparrows.
The air tastes of diesel and possibility.
A poet scribbles verses on a napkin, inspired
by the rhythm of couplings clanging like industrial wind chimes.
Through soot-streaked windows, the waking world
paints itself in streaks: barns bleeding red into fields,
vineyards stitching green up hillsides.
The dining car becomes a moving salon
where secrets are traded over bitter tea.
Every station passed is a life unlived,
every suitcase an alternate universe.
We chase horizons where the tracks converge,
forever becoming who we'll be upon arrival.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs.'
Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs.'

text.response:
The whistle pierces dawn's soft veil,
A metallic beast begins its tale.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
As wheels on tracks commence to finger
Their iron dance. Commuters sigh
While distant mountains scrape the sky.
A child points where sparrows fly
Past telegraph wires strung on high.
The rhythmic clack, a steady drum,
Announces journeys yet to come.
Briefcase warriors check their watches,
Lovers clutch like climbing rosettes
Against the window's foggy pane.
The city sheds its concrete chain
As green horizons start to bloom
Beyond the compartment's metal womb.
Each crossing bell, each station sign
Unfolds a new poetic line.
The porter's call, a brassy note,
Sails over coats and hats and throat
Of bustling hope. The engine's song
Grows stronger, faster, pushing on
Through tunnels where the darkness hums
Toward destinations yet unknown.
This transient world on gleaming rails
Carries more than human scales -
It bears the weight of morning's grace
In every hurried, hopeful face.

Steam curls like phantom fingers rise
As sunlight cracks the cobalt skies.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
In the coffee-scented air, where strangers
Mingle breaths. The conductor's shout
Sets nervous laughter rippling out
Across Platform 3. Without doubt
Adventure stirs as wheels turn about.
A businessman adjusts his tie,
A student waves a last goodbye,
An artist sketches fleeting trees
That blur like watercolor seas.
The iron horse begins its stride,
Pride swelling in each passenger's side.
Past brick factories sleeping still,
Beyond the water tower's hill,
Through neighborhoods where curtains part
To glimpse this transient moving art.
The rhythm pulses through the seats -
Life's metronome in clacking beats.
Each milepost marks a fresh new page
For young and old, for withered sage.
The dining car's bright silver clatter
Mingles hopes and mindless chatter.
As city spires shrink behind,
New landscapes free the captive mind.
This rolling world, this steel-bound dream
Carries more than it may seem.

Dewdrops cling to cold steel rails
As dawn's pink fingernail prevails
Against night's grasp. The station breathes
Expectant sighs through rusted wreaths
Of ivy. Suddenly - a hum,
A tremor through the platform's drum.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
Like perfume from a passing stranger.
Briefcase warriors check their phones
While through the speakers, hollow tones
Announce destinations bold:
"Next stop: stories yet untold!"
The doors exhale with hydraulic sigh,
Swallowing souls bound for the sky
Or sea or mountains. Ticket stubs
Become philosopher's stone nubs
Transforming routine into quest.
A toddler tugs his mother's vest,
Pointing where power lines sketch art
Against the sunrise. With a start,
The giant stirs - first hesitant creep
Then joyful gallop, leaping deep
Into the day. Commuters grin
As urban jungles grow thin,
Replaced by fields where fawns might pause.
The train becomes life's metaphor:
We're all just passengers aboard
Time's carriage. Window frames transform -
Each vista some exotic norm
For thirty seconds. Wheels sing clear:
"The world is vast, have no fear!"
This metal river, swift and bright,
Carries us from dark to light.

Platform pigeons scatter wide
As iron dragons wake inside
Their metal cocoons. High above,
A crescent moon still glows with love
For night. But hark! A piercing cry
Unzips the morning's muted sky.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
Like the aftertaste of ginger
In breakfast tea. The grind and squeal
Of brakes released becomes a peal
Of freedom's bell. Each window holds
A different story to unfold:
Here sits a widow clutching roses,
There a poet striking poses
To impress his seatmate. Luggage racks
Sag under dreams in knapsack sacks.
The locomotive gathers steam -
A waking giant from a dream
Of destinations. Whistle's shout
Says "Doubt no more! We're heading out!"
Past warehouses sleeping, graffiti-torn,
Where yesterday's newspapers are born
To line damp gutters. Signals blink
Like drunken stars about to sink.
The rhythm quickens - clack-clack-clack -
A heartbeat racing down life's track.
Farmhouses blink by, quick and quaint,
Each chimney puffing morning's paint.
The dining car becomes a stage
For friendships formed, for turning page
In life's great novel. Coffee spills
Like liquid courage that instills
Adventure. City's distant moan
Fades as the countryside takes throne.
This chariot of dawn's first light
Transforms commute to pure delight.

Mist embraces iron beams
While night retreats in silver streams
Of early light. The station clock
Ticks toward departure's final knock.
Then - sudden movement! Steel on steel
Awakens senses, makes hearts reel
With possibilities. You can hear the excitement start to linger
In the jostle of each eager finger
Gripping railings. Whistle's scream
Fractures dawn like shattered dream
Of stillness. Tickets flutter white
In hurried hands. The platform's bright
With anxious glances. Brakeman's wave
Signals journeys bold and brave.
The engine coughs, then finds its voice -
A deep-throated, resounding noise
That shakes the pigeons from their perch.
Now see the businessmen besmirch
Their polished shoes in sudden dash!
Hear satchels fall with wayward crash!
The rhythm builds - a chugging song
That says "Come ride where you belong!
Beyond the suburbs, past the mill,
Adventure waits!" Up climbs the hill
Of momentum. Window scenes
Flash by like interrupted dreams:
A boy on bicycle salutes,
Laundry on lines in birthday suits
Of colors, sleeping tractors stare.
The dining car's hot cocoa air
Mingles with hope. Strangers bond
O'er crossword clues and sights beyond
Their daily grind. The city's chain
Unshackles as we cross the plain
Of golden wheat. Each railroad tie
Counts moments passing swiftly by.
This steel centipede crawling through
The morning's fresh, expectant blue.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

text.response:
We have met before, in the haze of forgotten dreams,
Where time's river bends and softly gleams.
Your eyes held stories I couldn't quite recall -
Like faded frescoes on a crumbling wall.
Was it spring when cherry blossoms fell like snow?
Or winter's tale by firelight's amber glow?
Perhaps we whispered secrets to the moon,
Or danced barefoot to some forgotten tune.
Your laughter echoes in this empty room,
A half-remembered, lingering perfume.
Do you recall the bridge where swallows flew?
The way the willow wept just me and you?
Strange how the soul remembers what the mind forgets -
That quiet recognition when our gazes met.
Not strangers, no, but travelers on parallel roads
Who briefly shared life's unpredictable odes.

We have met before, stranger. I know your stride -
That hesitant shuffle, leaning leftward when you cried.
Your knuckles bear the scar from childhood's gate,
Just like the boy who shared my lemonade in '98.
The café smelled of cinnamon and rain
When you dropped your books and grinned through pain.
But now you pass me by with vacant stare,
As if we never braided daisies in our hair.
Perhaps you've folded memories away,
Like yellowed letters you won't reread today.
I won't remind you of the tree we climbed,
Where initials carved still mark our borrowed time.
Some meetings are like autumn leaves that fall -
Briefly golden, then no trace at all.

We have met before, my phantom twin.
In cracked mirrors where reflections begin
To bleed through dimensions. Your breath on the glass
Fogs my reality when centuries pass.
I've seen your shadow in Byzantine halls,
Heard your whispers in Carthaginian walls.
When Krakatoa roared its ashen plea,
Your fingerprints were left in Pompeii's debris.
Last Tuesday, buying milk at 3 AM,
Your spectral form reached for the same jam.
Parallel lives like tangled puppet strings -
Do you feel it too when the churchbell rings?
Our collisions warp space-time's design,
Leaving quantum bruises that eerily shine.
Next incarnation, check the produce aisle -
I'll be the one with the knowing half-smile.

We have met before, relentless sea.
Your salt-kissed waves still recognize me -
That shipwrecked sailor from '42
Whose waterlogged prayers returned to you.
You cradled me in turquoise delirium,
Gifting seashells like fragile memoriam.
Now I'm shoreline driftwood, bleached and worn,
Watching tides reclaim what they have sworn
To reunite. Your froth licks my bare feet
With liquid memories both bitter and sweet.
The gulls still scream our unfinished debate,
While starfish trace patterns of our shared fate.
In every conch's spiral I hear it clear:
"You've drowned in me a thousand times, my dear."

We have met before, my midnight thought.
When sanity's fragile lace comes undone,
You slither from corners where fears are caught,
Dressed in shadows of battles never won.
I know your knock - three taps, then a pause -
And how you melt keyholes without cause.
Last Tuesday you wore my dead father's face,
Tonight you'll quote verses from forbidden space.
Our conversations stain the ceiling black
With riddles only panic can unpack.
Why must you always rearrange my drawers?
Leave origami beasts on hardwood floors?
This dance we do in witching hours deep,
Where madness harvests what reason can't keep.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

text.response:
We have met before,
in the hush of twilight's sigh,
when the moon was a silver sliver
and the stars whispered lullabies.
Your eyes held galaxies I'd traversed,
your voice, a melody half-remembered
from dreams that dissolved at dawn.
Was it beneath the banyan's ancient roots,
where roots tangled like destinies?
Or on a rain-slicked city street,
reflections pooling at our feet,
mirroring faces we couldn't quite place?
Our hands brushed—a spark leapt—
a phantom touch from another life.
Now, as you stand before me,
strange yet achingly familiar,
I taste the salt of a sea we once sailed,
hear the echo of a promise
buried in the marrow of time.
We have met before,
not in flesh, but in the quiet spaces
between heartbeats,
in the map of constellations
etched upon our souls.

We have met before,
says the rust on the garden gate,
swinging on hinges worn smooth
by decades of comings and goings.
We have met before,
whispers the willow by the pond,
her branches trailing in water
that remembers every ripple.
I found you in the attic's dust,
an old photograph—sepia ghosts
smiling through cracked emulsion.
Your laugh, sudden in the stillness,
startled the sparrows from the eaves.
You handed me a pear from the orchard,
its flesh cool, sweet with secrets.
No names passed between us,
only the weight of recognition
heavy as summer thunder.
The path we walked
was overgrown with forgetfulness,
yet our feet knew each stone.
When twilight bled into indigo,
you vanished like mist off the fields.
But the gate still creaks your name,
and the willow weeps silver in moonlight.

We have met before.
Not in palaces or battlefields,
but in the liminal spaces:
the flicker between lamp posts at midnight,
the breath held before a storm breaks.
Once, you were the shadow
that danced just beyond my candle's reach.
Another time, a phrase in a forgotten tongue
that trembled on my lips as I woke.
I knew you when the clock struck thirteen
and reality frayed at the edges.
You left frost patterns on my window—
a forest of ferns only we could decipher.
Our encounters are footnotes
in the margins of chaos theory:
a dropped coin that rolled uphill,
a street musician’s tune
matching my pulse exactly.
No handshake, no exchange of names—
only the electric certainty
that our atoms have collided
in the dark matter of existence,
before time learned to march in straight lines.

We have met before,
in the year the rivers ran backwards
and crows wore crowns of thistle.
You were the blacksmith's apprentice,
hammering twilight into horseshoes.
I was the weaver spinning clouds
into bridal veils for the wind.
We traded riddles by crossroads
as owls judged from oak branches.
You stole a kiss behind the hayricks;
it tasted of wild strawberries and danger.
Then the wars came—crude, hungry things—
scattering us like chaff.
Centuries later, in this fluorescent-lit room,
your laugh hooks me like a fishbone
lodged in memory's throat.
That scar above your eyebrow—
did the anvil spark bite you
that midsummer eve?
The coffee machine gurgles.
Someone drops a tray.
But in the pause, I see the smithy's glow,
smell hay and hot iron.
We have met before.
Now, will you share my lunch?

We have met before,
says the scar on my left palm
when rain approaches.
It throbs like a compass needle
pointing to your longitude.
Once, you were the shard
of obsidian in my fist
as I faced the mountain cat.
Another life, you were the rope
I wove from desert grasses
to lower us into the canyon's heart.
I have tasted your blood in salt,
heard your warnings in earthquake tremors.
Today, you pass me a paperclip,
its metal cool and obedient.
Your fingers—unremarkable, smooth—
hold the memory of callouses
from hauling granite under a red sun.
We assemble spreadsheets under neon,
but our spines remember carrying stones
for a temple that sank into jungle.
The photocopier jams.
You sigh, and it’s the sound
of dry earth cracking.
We have met before.
This time, let’s build something
that floats.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'
Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

text.response:
We have met before, I'm certain of that trace,
In the crinkled corners of a half-remembered face.
Was it autumn when your laughter shook the golden trees?
Or spring when pollen drifted on the lilac-scented breeze?
Your voice contains old echoes - fragments I recall
From twilight conversations by some forgotten garden wall.
Perhaps in other lifetimes, wearing different skins,
We traded secrets softly as the moon's slow spin begins.
Or maybe just last Tuesday at the crowded subway station,
Two strangers sharing glances filled with silent recognition.
The universe replays us like a well-worn melody,
Threading souls through centuries with stubborn symmetry.
Don't ask for names or places - such details fade and fray -
But hold this quiet knowing as night bleeds into day:
Some meetings aren't beginnings, just familiar doors swung wide,
Two travelers recognizing landmarks carried deep inside.

We have met before, the earth confides to rain,
In canyon walls where ancient rivers carved their pain.
You were desert wind, I was stubborn acacia thorn,
Long before either woke to human form.
Recall when glaciers birthed us from blue ice?
Or volcanic ash that made us sacrifice
Old shapes to magma's forge? The mountains nod - 
They've watched our mineral dances pierce the sod.
Now in this borrowed flesh, we circle, strange yet known,
Like magnetite fragments to a polar field stone.
Beneath the skin, the bedrock hums a tune
Of tectonic embraces beneath the waning moon.
No handshake required when stone greets stone,
Just silent recognition in the marrow's bone.
We'll meet again as dust when stars forget our name,
Still singing lithic hymns from whence we came.

We have met before. Not you, perhaps, but this -
The way your teacup trembles as you lift it to your lips,
The sudden draft that chills the room, the clock's insistence,
The fractured light through blinds revealing dust's existence.
I know this script: the pause before you speak,
The nervous thumb that strokes your chipped front teeth.
Deja vu's cheap parlour trick? Don't be absurd.
I've lived this Tuesday with its damp grey birds
Six hundred times. Each creak of this café chair
Plays counterpoint to ghosts who sat right there.
That stain on ceiling tile? I've counted every blotch
While waiting for your words that never seem to match
The dialogue I memorized. Don't look surprised -
We're trapped inside this loop you've theorized.
Reset at midnight. Same bad coffee. Same strange plea:
"Have we met?" you ask. Always. Eternally.

We have met before, though maps dispute the claim.
Your hands held different calluses, my face another name.
Recall Constantinople? Silk Road dust still stains my dreams -
You sold me spices near the river's sunlit gleam.
Or colder shores where Viking sails tore northern gales apart?
I mended your torn cloak near Jorvik's bustling heart.
Perhaps as rival scholars in Timbuktu's hushed halls,
Debating star charts by dim lantern light's soft falls.
History's palimpsest rewrites our meetings:
A Cairo bazaar, Kyoto's fragile blossom greetings,
Tenochtitlan's canals where jade met Spanish steel -
Familiar ghosts in unfamiliar stories reel.
Don't trust chronology - it lies with linear art.
Our souls keep crumpled passports stitched across the heart.
That scar beneath your chin? From Krakow's winter blade.
I know. I stitched it. Memory's currency won't fade.

We have met before. The evidence? Your shadow
Detaches from the lamppost, starts to borrow
My footsteps down the wet November street.
It happened Tuesday last - the same deceit
Of pavement gleaming under sodium light,
Same hollow rhythm in the swallowing night.
You think you're new? Observe the alley cat
That freezes mid-stride, fur like shocked diplomat -
It knows your resonance. That puddle there
Reflects not current rain, but older air
From when we argued near this broken fence.
The raindrops whisper your old pretense.
Even this ache beneath my ribs feels second-hand -
A phantom bruise from when you let me understand
This isn't our first collision in the dark.
We'll keep repeating till we get the ending stark
And different. Till the script dissolves. Or we do.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

text.response:
We have met before, I know it's true,
In dreams where moonlit rivers flow,
Your eyes, that shade of twilight blue,
Recall a time from long ago.

Perhaps in Persia's golden hall,
Where poets spun their silken rhymes,
Or when the Roman trumpets' call
Echoed through ancient, conquered climes.

I recognize the curve of your hand
Tracing constellations on my spine,
Like sailors mapping foreign land
By patterns drawn in starry line.

Do you recall that monsoon rain
In Kolkata, where we shared chai?
Your laughter, soft as homebound train,
Beneath the bruised and weeping sky.

Or when the glaciers groaned and shifted,
Mammoths trumpeting icy air?
Our frozen breaths like ghosts that drifted
Through caves where painted bison stare.

Strange how the heart keeps buried traces
Of meetings lost to time's swift stream -
The tilt of head, familiar faces
That surface in memory's half-dream.

So tell me now, before we part,
Where did we last exchange this glance?
Was it Versailles? Or in your heart?
Or in some cosmic lovers' dance?

We have met before - the phrase hangs between us like cobwebs in an attic. I study your face: the scar above your eyebrow where childhood met pavement, the way your left incisor overlaps slightly, your habit of tapping ring fingers when nervous. These details live in my marrow.

It was Tuesday, 3:17pm. Rain streaked the bus window when you boarded. You wore mustard-yellow socks with ducks. Our knees brushed as you took the aisle seat. You smelled of bergamot and stale paperbacks. For seven stops we breathed the same humid air. When you rose at Elm Street, your umbrella hooked my sleeve. "Sorry," you murmured. "Quite alright," I replied. Neither smiled.

Now here you stand at this gallery opening, holding chardonnay. Your eyes widen - you remember too. That mundane Tuesday imprinted itself like a fossil in shale. Our collision of ordinary moments became extraordinary through recollection. The universe folds time into origami cranes; sometimes two creases align. We needn't speak of past lives - we've shared this one, fleetingly, profoundly.

We have met before - not in flesh but in ink. Between dog-eared page 73 and the coffee stain on chapter 12. You were the gardener in Brontë's storm, trimming hedges while lightning cracked the sky. I was the governess watching from attic windows, counting your steady snips between thunderclaps.

Later, you surfaced as the ferryman on Lethe's shores, poling souls through mist. My coin rested cold in your palm - our only contact. You murmured "Next?" without looking up. I boarded, forgetting.

In Murakami's jazz bar, you played bass behind smoky curtains. I sat nursing single malt, tracing your silhouette through beaded strings. Our eyes met during the piano solo. You nodded. I raised my glass. The song ended; you vanished behind amplifiers.

Now here you stand - real at last. Your hands hold calluses from imagined tools: pruning shears, oar handles, bass strings. I touch your wrist. "The garden needs trimming," I say. You smile. "The ferry's waiting." We walk into fog, finally written together.

We have met before - in the way seasons know each other. When autumn first blushes maple leaves, it remembers spring's shy crocuses. Your winter bones recall my summer sweat on shared bedrock.

We met when your grandmother planted the oak sapling. Seventy years later, I carved our initials where her thumb pressed soil. Your childhood fingerprints linger in the clay I wedge on my potter's wheel.

We met when your breath became mine through city smog - you exhaling in Tokyo, me inhaling in Cairo. Your discarded hair became nesting strands for sparrows outside my window.

We met in the carbon cycle: your fallen apple core feeding my dahlia tubers. In water cycles: your tears evaporating to nourish my monsoon.

"Have we met?" you ask. I point to glaciers weeping our ancient meltwater. To volcanoes exhaling our shared minerals. Our meeting isn't recollection - it's recognition. Not memory but ecology. We've always been exchanging atoms, trading raindrops, passing stardust hand to hand since supernovae first scattered us.

We have met before - but backwards. Today I stumble upon your farewell party. Confetti littering floorboards, champagne flutes abandoned. Your suitcase by the door. "Don't go," I beg, though we've just met.

Yesterday we fought bitterly over burnt toast - our first breakfast. Your accusations tasted of charcoal. I threw jam jar against fridge. It bled strawberry on linoleum.

Last week we slow-danced in that cramped apartment. Your head fit perfectly below my chin. We discovered your laugh sounds like ice cubes clinking.

Three months prior, I tripped over your outstretched legs in the library. "Sorry," we chorused. Your textbooks scattered: Advanced Quantum Physics. My sketchpad splayed open. You helped gather pages. Our fingertips touched.

Now at this party, you grip my shoulders. "Remember how we met?" Tears streak your face. I shake my head. You whisper: "In six months, you'll drop your keys outside Café Luna. I'll pick them up. We'll talk until sunrise."
Our first meeting awaits us. Our last just ended. Time folds like origami. We have met before - in memories waiting to happen.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

text.response:
We have met before, beneath this ancient oak,
Where shadows whispered secrets we once spoke.
Your eyes, like twilight pools, reflect a past
Where constellations of our souls were cast.
Recall the cobblestone in Paris rain?
Your laughter wove through alleyways again.
Or Kyoto's temple, cherry blossoms fell
Like memories we couldn't quite dispel.
Perhaps it was a dream where moonlight bled
On desert sands, your fingers tracing threads
Of stories woven in some other skin.
The universe contracts to let us in
To borrowed moments, echoes in the blood.
I know your silence, though you speak no word.
That tremor in your hand when leaves descend –
A thousand lifetimes couldn't make this end.
Our ghosts drink tea in corners of the room,
While present hearts navigate the gloom
Of knowing what we cannot quite recall:
That every meeting answers destiny's call.

We have met before? The phrase hangs, sharp and cold.
That stranger's gaze holds stories left untold.
Perhaps in Prague when fog ate Charles Bridge whole,
You sold me charms to save my tarnished soul.
Or wartime trenches, sharing rum-soaked bread,
Your voice the only comfort near the dead.
Maybe as rivals in Venetian masks,
Plotting betrayal in palazzos' tasks.
Or simpler: Tuesday's bus stop in the rain,
You dropped your umbrella, smiled through the pain.
Memory's a traitor – now your frown unlocks
A childhood treehouse built with stolen blocks.
That scar beneath your chin? From rollerblades
When we crashed laughing down suburban glades.
The mind erases what the heart retains:
Your coffee order, how you hum refrains
Of songs we never heard. This déjà vu
Is just life's glitch revealing what is true:
Some meetings aren't first acts, but encores staged
By time's director on a world enraged.

We have met before? The forest knows your tread.
This moss remembers how our footsteps bled
Into the earth last autumn. River stones
Still murmur of the burdens we'd outgrown.
That birch with eyes carved deep in silver bark
Watched us build kingdoms in the fading dark.
The wind recalls the promises we threw
Like maple seeds toward the vaulted blue.
You're in the raven's croak at break of day,
The pattern frost makes on the pane's display.
The creek still chants the lullaby we made
For fireflies trapped in jars that couldn't fade.
Mountains keep echoes of our shouted names,
And thunder rumbles ancient, foolish games.
Even the rain smells of your hair that night
We thought the stars would guide us right.
The land's a ledger where our meetings scrawl
In root and rock. Come winter, spring, or fall,
These pines will testify with solemn grace:
You left your shadow in this sacred space.

We have met before? Impossible! And yet...
Your tie's askew the way that Jenkins let
His lopsided bow dangle at the gala.
(His wife made scenes – oh, quite the scandal!)
That cough – distinctly Mrs. Gable's wheeze
From Tuesday bingo, loud enough to freeze
The daubers mid-air. And your pocket square
Matches the poodle's bow at County Fair!
Perhaps you're Doris' nephew? Short and keen,
Who stole my taxi in '08? Mean!
Or... wait... the man who screamed about the bees
When picnicking? You dropped your keys!
These clues collide like mismatched puzzle parts.
I'll solve you yet! Your smell – of tarts
And turpentine? Like Bert's Bakery fire!
Sir, were you there? Don't you conspire
With my confusion! Stop that whistled tune!
It's Madge's anthem every afternoon!
This déjà vu's a farce, I must insist –
Though why's there jam upon your wrist?

We have met before? In digital ether's glow,
Where avatars dance in the streams that flow
Through fiber veins. Your alias – Night_Rider?
We dueled in cyber castles, side by side.
Or was it dating apps? That pixelated grin
Above a bio promising no sin
Just coffee chats? Your memes feel eerily known:
That dancing cat with top hat, monocle shown.
Perhaps deep forums where we fiercely typed
Philosophies while anonymity striped
Our true selves bare. Your syntax rings a bell –
Those nested parentheses you wield so well.
Or gaming clans where voice chat bloomed at dawn,
Your laugh a glitchy melody now gone.
The net remembers every byte we shared,
Each cryptic emoji, how our keyboards flared
With arguments about AI's soul. My screen
Still holds the ghost of conversations seen
Through midnight blue light. Though we meet flesh-new,
Our data shadows recognize you.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

text.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
Where moss-kissed walls in twilight lay.
Its thatch, a nest for sparrows' wings,
Held echoes of forgotten springs.
The door, unlatched by seasons' hand,
Revealed a hearth where ghosts might stand.
In dusty beams that sliced the gloom,
Wild roses wove their living loom.

No chimney smoked, no candle glowed,
Just moonlit vines that softly flowed
Through broken panes like liquid light,
Transforming shadows into night's requite.
A rusted scythe by cold fireplace
Kept vigil in that empty space,
While field mice danced on earthen floor
Where laughter rang an age before.

This humble jar of sun-baked earth
Whispered of labor, love, and birth,
Of hands that shaped each muddy clod
To build a shelter from life's prod.
Now swallows dip where children played—
Time's tender debt to memory paid.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A sunken ship in meadow's bay.
Its walls, once sturdy, cracked and lean,
Bore witness to what storms had been.
The roof sagged low like weary bones,
Grown thick with ivy's climbing tones.
A single window, eye askew,
Reflected skies of changing hue.

Inside, the scent of damp and thyme
Preserved the rhythm of lost time.
A wooden table, scarred and gray,
Held autumn leaves in disarray.
Where clay met timber, beetles drilled
Through secrets that the structure filled.

Outside, a well of crumbling stone
Stood guardian, forever alone.
Beneath the elderberry's shade,
The cottage slowly was unmade:
Each rain dissolved its earthen skin,
Returning what was shaped within
To hungry soil that gave it form—
Life's quiet, constant, gentle storm.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A humble vessel of yesterday.
Its walls, though weathered, warmly stood
Against the wind in solitude.
The doorframe curved like grandma's spine,
Bearing the years with grace divine.
Geraniums, stubborn and bright,
Flamed in the windows, claiming light.

Within, the scent of fresh-baked bread
(Or memory's trick?) around me spread.
A rocking chair with faded blue
Swayed as if someone lately drew
Its motion—perhaps a phantom wife
Still knitting threads of her own life?

Beneath the eaves, a swallow's nest
Held speckled eggs in downy rest.
The clay, still breathing cool and deep,
Guarded the dreams of those asleep
Forever in its earthen breast:
Laborers finding final rest.
This crumbled ark of sun-dried sod
Held conversations with the god
Of simple things: rain, wheat, and toil—
Earth's everlasting, quiet spoil.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Half-swallowed by the green affray
Of nettles, docks, and climbing bines
That wove through cracks like living vines.
A crooked path of mossy stone
Led to its threshold, overgrown.
The chimney stack, a crumbling tower,
Sundered by lightning in some fierce hour.

Inside, the shadows pooled like ink
Where once a family shared their drink.
A child's doll with button eyes
Watched spiders spin their silken ties
Across the nook where beds once stood—
All gone to dust and rotten wood.

Yet in decay, fierce beauty thrived:
Through shattered tiles, poppies dived
To drink the light. In every flaw,
Nature reclaimed what humans saw
As ruin. Beetles drilled new art
In timber ribs. This house's heart
Beat not in walls, but in release—
A slow surrender unto peace.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Where art and earth held gentle sway.
Each hand-smoothed curve, each bulging line,
Told of the maker's deep design:
Not right angles but flowing forms,
Shaped like a pitcher keeping warm
Against the breast of patient craft.
No architect's cold, measured draft,
But fingers coaxing mud to rise
Beneath a vast, approving sky.

The walls breathed cool in summer's blaze,
In winter held the hearth's warm gaze.
The rounded niches, smooth as eggs,
Held secrets in their earthen legs.
Blue door—a splash of lapis hue—
Framed by wild grapes' embracing view.

Now, though the roof lets moonlight spill
Like milk across the windowsill,
The cottage sings its maker's praise
In every sun-baked, rain-softened phase.
A masterpiece of transient grace,
It melts—an earthy, slow embrace—
Back to the fields from whence it came,
Leaving no mark except love's claim.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

text.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
Its walls like sun-baked earth's display.
The thatch was frayed, a ragged crown,
Where swallows dipped and fluttered down.
A crooked chimney, smoke-stained grey,
Told tales of winters passed away.
The garden slept in tangled rest,
With poppies nodding on its breast.
Through leaden panes, a candle's gleam
Danced like a long-forgotten dream.
I thought of hands that shaped this nest:
How many hearts here found their rest?
The door hung slack on rusted hinge,
A threshold crossed by time's own fringe.
That humble dwelling, low and deep,
Held memories that stones could keep -
Of laughter by the fireside seat,
Of weary souls and shuffling feet.
Now silent under moon's soft stare,
It breathes the scent of thyme and air,
A testament to simple ways
That marked the passage of our days.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Half-swallowed by the hillside's sway.
Its earthen bones embraced by roots
Where saplings wore their leafy suits.
A mossy roof, all green and deep,
Where rain and centuries would weep.
The windows, eyes of clouded glass,
Watched seasons like a patient pass.
Inside, the ghosts of potters dwelled -
Whose deft thumbs shaped this humble shelled
Abode. Their kiln's forgotten heat
Still warms the stones where wild things meet.
Now rabbits trace the crumbling wall,
And ivy weaves its funeral pall.
That clay-born shelter, stout and wise,
Reflects the earth in patient guise.
No marble tomb could stand as true
As this soft form the rains renew.
It melts like honey in the sun,
Returning to the One begun.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A lonely sentinel at day's decay.
Around it moaned the moorland wind,
Seeking the warmth it left behind.
No hearth now glowed in that dark room,
Just shadows dancing with the gloom.
The clay had cracked like ancient skin,
Revealing where the years had been.
Yet in the doorway, stark and bare,
A single wild rose bloomed there -
A splash of pink against the grey,
Defying time's relentless sway.
I thought of hands that mixed the earth,
What humble dreams had given birth
To walls that held against the storm?
What humble heart kept silence warm?
Now only beetles roam the floor
Where children played by yonder door.
That earthen shell, so frail, so slight,
Holds constellations in the night.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Where river reeds in whispers sway.
Reflected in the slow brown stream,
It seemed a vessel in a dream.
The waterlilies kissed the walls
When summer's heavy rainfall calls.
Dragonflies on clay banks perched,
As if the very mud had birched
Life from the silt. Inside, I knew,
The river's breath seeped through and through.
Clay melting back to mother mud,
Returning to the primal flood.
No human step disturbed the silt,
Where water spiders built their tilt.
The cottage wept with damp delight,
Dissolving in the liquid light.
Its contours softened, blurred, erased -
A memory by liquid traced.
Soon otters slide where tables stood,
In this clay womb of riverhood.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Where desert winds at twilight play.
Adrift in dunes of golden sand,
A handprint from a vanished hand.
Its roof-beam curved like Bedouin tents,
Baked hard by sun, without relent.
No tree cast shade upon its face,
Just scorpions in the cool embrace
Of shadowed corners. Oven-hot,
The clay remembered what was wrought
By tribes who shaped the earth to form
Shelter against the raging storm.
Now stars pierce holes in crumbling walls,
As night's great tapestry installs
Its silver map. The nomads gone,
The desert claims what they had won.
That clay abode, so stark and bare,
Whispers to stars with ancient air -
A monument to transient grace
Carved in time's ever-shifting space.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

text.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
With walls that the seasons had worn,
Where ivy crept up in a silent ballet,
And moss on the threshold was born.
Its roof, like a weary man's shoulders,
Sagged under centuries' weight,
While through cracks in the timber, bold spiders
Spun dreams of a bygone estate.
The chimney stood cold without laughter,
No hearth-smoke to soften the grey,
Just swallows that nested in rafter
And carried the sunbeams away.
I wondered what hands kneaded earthen mud,
What hopes shaped these humble walls,
Did children once splash in the nearby flood?
Did love fill these echoing halls?
Now only the wind tells its stories
To nettles that guard the front gate,
A monument carved by life's glories
And time's patient, whispering weight.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Half-sunken in peat-bog's embrace,
Where will-o'-wisps dance at end of day
And water snakes weave through the space.
Its windows like hollow-eyed sockets
Stare into marshland's deep green,
Where secrets are kept in stone pockets
And roots weave what man has not seen.
They say when the moon bleeds crimson,
A woman in tattered grey gown
Appears at the door, barely glimpsed on
The edge of the marsh's wet crown.
She sings of a child lost to fever,
A husband who sailed never back,
Her grief makes the bog-weeds shiver,
Her tears stain the clay walls pitch-black.
The cottage drinks sorrow like water,
Grows thicker with each passing year,
A vessel for love's cruel slaughter
That traps ghosts within walls held dear.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A hermit's snug fortress it seemed,
With cabbages guarding the pathway
And bees in the hollyhocks dreamed.
Inside lived Elias the mender,
Who fixed what the world threw away:
Clocks with no hands, stilled in surrender,
And dolls with eyes moulded to grey.
His walls were patched thrice-over neatly,
His kettle sang songs on the hob,
He'd mend broken things completely
While munching on sweet cob of corn.
He showed me a music box treasure
That played stars instead of a tune,
And mended my soul with such pleasure
Beneath the midsummer moon.
That cottage held more than earth's plaster—
It cradled the art of repair,
Where nothing was deemed a disaster,
Just life needing delicate care.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A relic of simpler design,
Before concrete learned to hold sway
And steel skeletons redefined
Our sense of what shelter should be.
This hut breathed with earth's patient sigh,
Cool in heat, warm when frost ran free,
A partnership 'neath open sky.
Now modern homes, sterile and tall,
Deny seasons' shifting embrace,
With thermostats ruling the hall
And sealed windows hiding time's face.
But clay walls remember the rain,
Expand with each damp-laden gust,
Contract when drought rules the plain—
This wisdom in granules of dust.
Let skyscrapers scrape heaven's blue,
This cottage in quiet decline
Teaches what man forgot: it's true—
The best homes let earth's rhythms shine.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And wondered: if walls could recount,
What tales would they choose to convey?
Perhaps of a fox by the mount
Who napped in the shade of the eaves,
Or lovers who carved heart and name
On oak beams (the blade still retrieves
Their passion from wood's quiet claim).
The threshold knows work-worn boots scraping,
The hearth-stones recall simmered stews,
The loft beams hold harvests escaping
From sacks split by rodentish chews.
If raindrops that slid down its cheek
Could gather like beads on a string,
They'd whisper in moisture-soft speak
Of winters that turned spring to spring.
This cottage—a library standing,
Each crack is a sentence half-told,
Its history ever demanding
We listen to stories it holds.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

text.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
With walls that the seasons had worn away,
Its thatch like a grey bird's ruffled wing,
Cradling silence that only spring
Could break with the nesting wren's sharp cry.
Smoke curled from its chimney, thin and high,
A ghostly thread in the twilight air,
As if the earth itself breathed there.
The door stood open - a dark, warm mouth -
Where shadows gathered, drifting south
With stories carved in wooden beams,
Whispering of forgotten dreams.
Clay-cradled hearth with embers low,
Holding centuries of sun and snow,
While ivy fingers, green and deep,
Guarded secrets the stones would keep
Of laughter spilled on earthen floors
And quiet grief behind closed doors.
This humble hold against the years,
A vessel for both joy and tears,
Stood rooted where the wild thyme grows,
Wearing time like a well-loved rose.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Moon-pale beneath the Milky Way,
Where night-blooming flowers breathed perfume
Through window cracks in the midnight gloom.
Inside, a loom with threads of gold
Wove starlight into cloth, I'm told,
By the crone who stirred her cauldron bright
With silver fish that leapt in light.
Her clay walls pulsed with ancient rhyme,
Beating in time with cosmic chime.
When owls called from twisted yew,
Her kettle sang the dawn anew,
While clay-born spirits danced in rings
To cricket orchestras on muted strings.
That cottage stood where worlds entwine -
A seam where earth and stars align.
Each crack held galaxies inside,
Where cosmic dust and hope abide.
At dusk, it seemed to fade from view,
A dream the waking world never knew.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Abandoned since market day
When plague carts rolled through mud-rutted lanes,
Leaving only the wind's low refrains.
The roof slumped like a tired mare's back,
The garden surrendered to thistle attack.
Where children chased chickens in sun-dappled yards,
Now only the wary fox prowls and regards
The cold hearth where no kindling's laid,
The table where no grace is prayed.
A rusted scythe leans by the door -
Harvests forgotten forevermore.
Clay walls weep when the rain descends,
Washing away what time defends.
Through broken panes, the seasons blow:
Drifting snow, bluebell's indigo.
This monument to vanished hands
Slowly returns to shifting sands.
Yet in decay, a stubborn grace -
Earth reclaiming its dwelling place.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And instantly knew I must stay.
Its crooked charm called like a song
That whispered, 'Here's where you belong.'
I patched the roof with river reeds,
Cleared nettle-knots from choking weeds,
Chinked walls with moss and lime-washed white,
Made windows glow with candlelight.
My hands learned clay's forgiving ways -
Imperfect edges merit praise.
I baked bread in the rounded hearth,
Felt solitude's unexpected worth.
Rain's rhythm on my earthen floor
Is sweeter than rich wood before.
Wrens nest above my clay-built door,
Proving simplicity's encore.
This humble hold, my soul's reprieve,
Teaches how little one needs to live:
Warmth, quiet, and the patient art
Of listening to one's own heart.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Where the potter's children used to play.
His wheel still turned by the garden wall,
Though master and laughter recall
Only the swallows that nest each spring
In rafters where clay-daubed dreams take wing.
Clay dust lingered in sunbeam streams,
Floating through forgotten schemes
Of pitchers, bowls, and garden urns -
Life's vessel each creation yearns.
The cottage breathed with earthen lungs,
Its very essence clay among
The riverbanks where he sourced his art,
Molding patience into every part.
Now weeds grow through the cooling kiln,
But something lingers in the stillness still:
The thrum of creation's sacred thread
In every clay-crafted wall and bed.
This house remembers each gentle press -
Earth formed with love, nothing less.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

text.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
Where swallows dip in evening's sigh,
Its walls, sun-baked through endless day,
Hold echoes of the wind's low cry.
The thatch, a nest for creeping vine,
Wears seasons like a weathered face,
Where rain has drawn its silver line
And time has carved a gentle trace.

Inside, the ghosts of hearth-smoke drift,
Of bread once broke on oakwood boards,
Of hands that lifted harvest's gift
From fields that sleep as autumn hoards.
The door, unlatched, invites the moon
To dance upon the earthen floor,
A vessel for night's tender tune
That seeps through cracks forevermore.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A slumped form in the meadow's breast,
Where buttercups hold court by day
And foxes carve their hidden nest.
Its windows, blank as tired eyes,
Reflect the clouds' slow caravan,
While chimney-swallows chart the skies
Above this humble home of man.

The lintel bears a lover's mark -
Two names scored deep in timber grain,
Now washed by storms into the dark
Like tears on weathered windowpane.
Yet still it stands, this earthen shell,
A monument to patient hands
That shaped the dirt and made it dwell
Between the river and the lands.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Where goblin-moss paints emerald dreams
On walls that lean in disarray
Beside the creek's bright liquid seams.
At midnight when the owls take flight,
The cottage breathes a spectral sigh -
Its clay remembers ancient light
From when the stars were drawing nigh.

Beneath the warped and creaking sill,
A trove of moonbeam-dust is stored,
Where twilight weaves her subtle thrill
Through keyholes to the shadowed hoard.
The hearth still hums with phantom fire,
Though fifty winters came and passed,
Its clay still thrums with wild desire
To hold the magic that will last.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A stubborn knuckle in the field,
That braves the tempest's fierce array
And to the gale refuses yield.
Its back bent low 'gainst western gales,
Its face turned east to greet the dawn,
It tells of life's enduring tales
In cracks where wild thyme creeps upon.

The clay remembers kneading hands
That mixed the earth with chaff and straw,
Built shelter where the pilgrim stands
To watch the season's grinding maw.
Though roof sags like a weary thought,
Though plaster flakes like ancient skin,
The cottage guards what time has wrought -
The stubborn peace that dwells within.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Half-swallowed by the climbing green,
Where brambles claim the doorstep way
And kingfishers patrol the stream.
Inside, the scent of loam persists,
Of mushrooms growing in the gloom,
Where sunlight, in reluctant twists,
Dapples the abandoned room.

The garden sleeps beneath wild grass,
A phantom path where roses bled,
While through the broken looking-glass
The ghosts of children nod their head.
Each raindrop writes upon the floor
Ephemeral and liquid runes,
Recording what came long before
In clay beneath the waning moons.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

text.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
Where time had etched its story deep,
Its walls, like parchment, worn and grey,
Secrets in every crack they keep.
The thatch, a nest for sparrows' flight,
Sagged low beneath the weight of years,
While chimney smoke, a wispy white,
Danced with the wind, dispelling fears.
Through ivy-clad and crooked door,
A hearth once blazed with warmth and cheer,
Now silent stones on earthen floor,
Hold memories of laughter dear.
Yet in decay, a beauty dwells—
A testament to lives well-spent,
Where nature's breath softly compels
The clay to earth, with sweet consent.
This humble shrine to simple days,
Stands weathered, strong, and nobly plain,
A monument to rustic ways,
That sings of sun, and wind, and rain.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Emerging from the morning mist,
A sentinel at break of day,
By dewy meadows softly kissed.
Its sunken roof, a mossy crown,
Its windows, eyes that watch the lane,
Where generations laid down
Their joys and sorrows, peace and pain.
Within, the scent of loam and bread,
Of herbs hung drying from the beams,
Of dreams once nurtured, hopes once fed,
Like sunlight in forgotten streams.
Outside, a garden runs to wild,
Where roses climb with thorny grace,
And Time, that ever-questing child,
Has left its slow, embracing trace.
This clay-born haven, frail yet grand,
Still breathes the soul of simpler years,
A gentle fortress in the land,
Washed by the moonlight, dried by tears.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A humble thumbprint on the hill,
Where swallows dart in light of day,
And twilight wraps in shadows still.
Its walls, once warm with summer's glow,
Now crumble slow like ancient stone,
Yet in their ruin, life seeds grow—
Wallflowers bloom where cracks have shown.
A door hangs open to the field,
Inviting winds to sweep inside,
Where harvests once were stored and sealed,
And love was never forced to hide.
The hearth now cold, the table bare,
But spirits linger in the air—
The echo of a lullaby,
The ghost of pies that steamed nearby.
This earthen vessel, cracked and lean,
Still holds the music of the earth,
A quiet, unpretentious scene
That measures humble living's worth.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Half-buried in the willow's shade,
Where memories of yesterday
In every sunbeam are displayed.
The chimney, like a weary spine,
Still points where stars begin to gleam,
Though vines around its bricks entwine,
And frost has split the window's seam.
Inside, the dust motes dance and play
Through sunlit shafts that pierce the gloom,
Revealing where children once lay
In trundle beds in that small room.
The clay, now mixed with fallen leaves,
With insect homes and rootlets fine,
A sanctuary that receives
New life from each decaying line.
So death gives birth on every side—
The cottage melts into the ground,
A gentle, slow, and sacred tide
Where human craft and nature bound.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Like some primordial creature's shell,
Abandoned to the wind's relay,
A perfect, weathered, crumbling cell.
No gilded trim, no marble sill,
Just honest earth and honest toil,
Built where the stream runs down the hill,
On modest, unassuming soil.
The clay remembers human hands
That molded walls with care and sweat,
That shaped these curves from river sands
And packed the floors where footsteps met.
Now owls nest where cradles swung,
And beetles drill the doorframe deep,
While cobwebs, silver-fine and young,
Their silent, watchful vigils keep.
This earthen husk, so frail, so slight,
Outlasts the towers built of pride,
For clay returns to clay by night,
And humble things have naught to hide.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

text.response:
Under the moon's pale shroud, we gather near,
A silent cortege bound by grief and fear.
The hearse a shadowed boat on midnight's stream,
Carrying dreams that drowned in sleep's deep seam.
No organ's wail, just crickets' dirge instead,
As stars like candles watch above the dead.
This velvet hour swallows whispered cries,
Where mourning doves replace laments and sighs.
The freshly turned earth exhales winter's chill,
Accepting one last dance against their will.
We bury memories with the coffin's descent—
Photographs and laughter daylight lent.
Night funerals hold truth too stark for sun:
That darkness comes for everyone, undone.
The headstones stand as sentries in the gloom,
While living souls return to lighted rooms,
Leaving behind what moonlight can't restore—
A name, a date, and nothingness before.

Midnight's procession moves without a sound,
Where city lamps cast puddles on the ground.
Black umbrellas bloom like poisoned flowers
Beneath rain-slicked, indifferent towers.
The deceased rides through their former street—
Neon signs perform their homage fleet.
A jazz horn wails from some dim basement door,
Syncopated grief we can't ignore.
This urban burial lacks nature's grace;
Concrete and steel define the resting place.
Subway trains beneath our feet intone
Their rumbling requiem through pavement stone.
We clutch cheap flowers, dew replaced by smog,
While taxi headlights pierce the choking fog.
No country quiet here—just grinding gears
Mourning a life measured in working years.
The grave yawns where park benches used to stand,
Swallowing a dreamer's unclaimed land.

They came with lanterns shaped like fireflies
To lay the baker down beneath moonrise.
His coffin smelled of yeast and cinnamon,
A final loaf this patient craftsman spun.
The village brought his favorite honey cake,
Placed by the grave for destiny to take.
No priest presided, just his widow's prayer
And children tossing rosemary in air.
The night embraced him like well-kneaded dough,
As constellations only bakers know—
Orion's oven, Cassiopeia's knife—
Guided his passage to eternal life.
Soft flour ghosts danced in the burial pit,
While mourning doves watched silently from flit.
We left him with his rolling pin and pride,
Where dawn would find wheat growing from his side—
Golden stalks rising where his body lay,
Transforming sorrow into bread next day.

Consider the corpse's view: six feet above,
Hearing the shovel's scrape they used to love
When gardening in spring's forgiving light.
Now earth returns as uncompromising night.
They feel no tears that on coffin wood fell,
Nor hear the preacher's manufactured hell.
The velvet lining? Scratchy as burlap sack.
The eulogy? Just voices fading black.
Worms write sonnets in the margins now,
Roots crack symphonies through burial vow.
What fools these mortals be with their lament,
When decomposition is the sacrament!
Stars pierce the soil like celestial pins—
No judgment waits where true decay begins.
While living clutch their meaningless goodbyes,
The dead taste midnight's undisguised surprise:
Freedom from clocks and breath and being known,
At last, deliciously, completely alone.

The sea conducts its funeral at night—
No casket, just a skiff with one dim light.
Waves chant the liturgy in tidal rhyme,
Returning sailor to the arms of time.
Salt spray becomes the incense for this rite,
As phosphorescence crowns the passing bright.
His ashes swirl with krill and plankton bloom,
A living shroud within the ocean's womb.
No headstone but the coral's slow ascent,
No dirge but whale song's ancient testament.
The moon pulls silver ribbons 'cross the deep,
Where memory and water merge in sleep.
Grief ebbs like shoreline from the mourners' feet,
While currents weave eternity's winding-sheet.
He joins the driftwood and the nautilus shell,
Becoming what the tides alone can tell—
A billion glittering returns to shore
In mermaid's purse and conch forevermore.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

text.response:
The hearse glides through obsidian streets,
Where gas lamps weep their amber tears,
As shadowed mourners shift like ghosts,
Their whispered grief the night now hears.

A velvet casket holds what's left
Of laughter, stories, warmth, and grace—
The moon, a pallid witness high,
Turns clouds to lace upon its face.

No sun to mock this grim parade,
Just stars that pierce the vast unknown;
Each step on gravel echoes sharp,
A metronome of loss intoned.

They lower husks to hungry earth,
While roots below begin their feast—
Life’s banquet ends in silent dark,
Where worms compose the final peace.

Then headlights fade like dying dreams,
Leaving the fresh-turned soil alone,
As night resumes its endless watch
Above the newly claimed throne.

Midnight tolls the iron bell,
Black roses drape the carriage door,
A widow’s veil collects the dew,
As death knocks thrice then thrice once more.

No choir sings beneath the pines,
Just wind through branches, low and keen,
The coffin sinks in liquid dark,
Where memories dissolve unseen.

Owl eyes gleam from mossy stones,
Recording names in feathered scrolls—
Each shovel’s bite of clay and root
Unearths what fractured moonlight stole.

Mourners clutch their candle flames,
Tiny suns against the dread,
Until dawn’s grey and creeping hand
Extinguishes the living dead.

What lingers when the last car leaves?
A void where absence carves its mark,
And night, that patient undertaker,
Swallows even the faintest spark.

They buried him beneath the yew
When stars were sharp as broken glass,
No dirge played by the frozen stream,
Just silence stretched like winter grass.

The gravediggers with moon-pale skin
Drank whiskey neat to numb the chill,
While children dreamed of dancing bones
Beyond the cemetery hill.

His pocket watch still ticks somewhere
In velvet depths where darkness feeds,
Counting moments never lived,
Planting regrets like phantom seeds.

Earth receives what flesh discards,
A loan returned with interest due—
Night funerals trade in whispers,
Paid in tears and midnight dew.

By morning, only tire tracks
Remain on mud-slicked, lonely lanes,
Proof that darkness came and went
Leaving nothing but the stains.

Candles gutter in the wind,
Procession slow as clotting blood,
Each mourner wrapped in private night
And solitude’s unyielding flood.

No angels guard this sunless rite,
Just crows that croak from iron rails,
Their beaks like scythes that harvest naught
But echoes in these haunted vales.

The coffin—blacker than the void—
Swallows light with greedy glee,
A vessel bound for nowhere’s shore
On seas of black infinity.

What hymns exist for such an hour?
The midnight psalm has yet been writ,
So silence chants the liturgy
While weeping willows bow and spit.

When last clod falls on hollow wood,
The living turn from death’s embrace—
But night remains, forever stained
By graves it cannot quite erase.

See how the lanterns sway and dip
Like drunken fireflies in the gloom,
Guiding the dead through final paths
To chambers carved in earth’s dark womb.

The preacher’s words are swallowed whole
By fog that slithers low and cold,
While graveyard statues twist their necks
To watch the newest story told.

This night funeral needs no tears—
The corpse has shed its mortal weight,
Escaping time’s relentless wheel
To join the stars in tranquil state.

Beneath the lilacs, damp with dread,
A single cricket rasps a tune,
Composing odes for those who sleep
Beneath the ever-watchful moon.

Dawn’s fingers pry apart the dark,
But night’s soft shroud will come anew—
For every dusk holds funeral rites
For daylight’s dreams we thought we knew.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

text.response:
Night funeral, hearse wheels crack the silence,
A slow parade beneath the sycamore trees.
Mourners huddle like inkblots on parchment,
Breathing frost into the October freeze.

This death arrived without trumpet or drum,
Just the rustle of satin against pine.
The preacher's words dissolve in the gloom,
As stars puncture the velvet design.

Casket descends into earth's hungry jaw,
Moonlight silver on shovel and spade.
We linger where roots will rewrite the law
Of flesh becoming forest-made.

Owl's cry pierces the ritual pause,
Reminding us life's relentless beat
Continues despite our grieving laws,
As darkness swallows the shroud-wrapped sleeper.

We scatter like seeds in the mourning air,
Carrying fragments of absence home,
While night resumes its ordinary care
Of shadows and wind, utterly alone.

Midnight's procession moves without sound,
Coal-black cars devouring the road.
Grief wears concrete shoes in this town
Where sorrow's heavy currency is owed.

Faces float like pale balloons
Beneath the flickering gaslamp's stare.
Each mourner hums death's different tune:
Regret, relief, or simple despair.

Six feet down, the ritual complete,
Earth reclaims what breath once warmed.
Worms begin their sacred work,
Transforming what was once life-formed.

Above, a bat performs tight spirals,
Indifferent to human tears below.
Night's cathedral holds no requiems,
Only the wind's relentless flow.

We drive away with hollow chests,
Leaving darkness to guard the plot.
Dawn will find the grave undressed,
But night remembers what day forgot.

The hearse glides through obsidian streets,
A shark cutting through ink-black waves.
Death's perfume—chrysanthemum sweets—
Clings to velvet lapels like slaves.

Gravediggers smoke in yew tree shade,
Watching shadows perform their play.
This nightly transaction has been made
Since the first dawn turned to gray.

No applause for the starring role
Of this quietus dressed in wood.
Just the nightshift of the soul
Doing what the daylight could.

Mole noses twitch below the clay,
Waiting for this fresh descent.
Death's but the closing of a day,
Life the brief scent it lent.

When last spade of dirt is thrown,
The living turn toward neon's glare.
But the moon claims the buried bone,
Holding vigil beyond all care.

Midnight procession: headlights slice the fog,
A cortege crawling through sleeping streets.
