Death wears formal dress without epilogue,
While insomnia's lonely watch it meets.

Widow's veil flutters like moth wings,
Catching lamplight's golden snare.
The church bell's hollow mourning rings,
Tangling in the damp night air.

Coffin sinks—a shipwreck's plunge—
Into soil's cold and waiting arms.
Life's brief, bright lantern has been doused,
Leaving only memory's fading charms.

Night creatures pause in their foraging,
Sensing gravity's solemn shift.
Fox freezes near a trash can's edge,
Watching darkness swallow this gift.

We drive home through the indifferent town,
Past lit windows where dramas unfold.
Death's just a temporary crown
Worn before returning to mold.

Lanterns bob like drowned stars
Along the cemetery's blackened path.
Night absorbs our mortal scars
And cools the aftermath.

This burial under Ursa's gaze
Seems both too small and too immense.
Moonlight on the coffin plays,
A silver recompense.

Mourners clutch their woolen coats,
Shielding hearts from autumn's blade.
The deceased floats in memory's boats,
While worms begin their trade.

Owl observes from oak tree throne,
Silent judge of this dark rite.
Life's brief, flickering candle blown,
Returned to endless night.

We leave as dawn begins to creep,
Rubbing eyes raw from sorrow's weight.
But night keeps vigil, deep on deep,
At eternity's open gate.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

text.response:
Under a bruised plum sky they lowered the box, 
A night funeral in the whispering field. 
No sun to gild the preacher's watchful rocks, 
Just crickets chanting what the damp earth concealed. 
Black coats melted into shadow's embrace 
While coffin sank in moon-silvered mud. 
A widow's lace veil brushed death's bitter trace 
As roots drank tears where ancient oaks once stood. 
No motorcade with blinding halogen glare, 
Just pine scent sharp as grief on frozen air. 
Each shovelful of dirt made hollow sound 
That echoed through the valley's sleeping crown. 
Stars blinked cold approval overhead 
For souls returning to their earthen bed. 
The night absorbed the sorrow, drop by drop, 
Till silent mourners heard the darkness stop 
And turn towards dawn's grey, unfeeling light - 
The world unchanged by one extinguished light.

City night funeral: neon crosses weep 
Reflections in the rain-slicked avenue. 
A hearse idles where gutter-rivers creep, 
Disgorging grief in monochrome tableau. 
Black umbrellas bloom like poisoned flowers 
Beneath the flickering streetlamp's jaundiced eye. 
The mortuary scent of winter hours 
Clings to bricks where spectral pigeons cry. 
No hymns ascend through smog-choked atmosphere, 
Just muffled sobs the concrete canyon traps. 
Six pallbearers maneuver through the fear 
Past dumpsters overflowing with collapse. 
The subway rumbles underneath the pain 
As dirt meets varnished wood in rhythm strange. 
Alley cats observe from fire escape perches 
This nightly ritual where urban darkness lurches. 
One less shadow now walks these concrete shores - 
The city digests death behind locked steel doors.

Midnight procession through the sleeping town, 
Lanterns bobbing like low-hanging fruit. 
The coffin sways as men in black gowns 
Tread paths where frost has laid its silver suit. 
No weeping mars the stillness of the hour, 
Just boots on gravel crunching funeral songs. 
The churchyard gate creaks open to devour 
This offering darkness patiently prolongs. 
A child peers through a curtain's threadbare slit 
Watching shadows dance beyond her windowpane. 
She wonders why the grown-up faces fit 
Such peculiar masks carved out of pain. 
The gravedigger's shovel scrapes a stony note 
That mingles with the wind in ancient oaks. 
They leave the mound beneath the moon's pale coat 
And melt like ink in dawn's approaching strokes. 
By breakfast time, the fresh-turned earth smells sweet 
Where night had laid its melancholy feat.

What strange nocturnal harvest gathers here? 
The night-blooming cereus of final rest. 
No daylight witnesses the falling tear 
That soaks the velvet lining of death's chest. 
The mortuary moths attend in force 
Beating pale wings against the chapel glass. 
The corpse becomes the ceremony's source - 
Anchoring grief in this dark ocean pass. 
Embalming fluid glows with ghostly light 
As undertakers move with oiled precision. 
Their practiced hands make beautiful the blight 
Of rigor mortis in its grim position. 
The widow's trembling hand becomes a leaf 
Shaking in night winds of relentless sorrow. 
This floral clock unwinds beyond belief 
Stealing today, denying tomorrow. 
When morning comes with vulgar gold display 
The night funeral's guests have slipped away.

Hear the night funeral's peculiar song: 
A duet between shovel and cricket's chirr. 
The moon drags shadows where they don't belong 
As gravediggers disturb what slept in her. 
Nocturnal creatures pause their hungry hunt 
To watch the spectacle of mortal dread. 
An owl abandons mouse beneath a stump 
When six men lower stillness on a thread. 
The earth receives with neither joy nor rage 
This parcel wrapped in mahogany and brass. 
Night air grows thick on this peculiar stage 
Where living actors play their mortal farce. 
A pocket watch chimes softly in the gloom 
Marking time's victory in velvet dark. 
One candle struggles in the damp tomb 
Until a breeze extinguishes its spark. 
Dawn finds the scene wiped clean of midnight's trace - 
Just dew on roses marking death's embrace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'
Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

text.response:
The hearse crawls through obsidian streets,
where streetlamps weep amber tears on concrete.
Mourners huddle like shadows taking form,
whispering hymns the night tries to swallow whole.
Coffin sinks into earth's black maw—
a mouth hungry for finality.
Stars bear witness, cold and detached,
while moths beat wings against funeral wreaths
like lost souls begging entry.
Dirt hits polished wood with hollow thuds,
each shovelful a period closing sentences
of laughter, quarrels, Sunday breakfasts.
The widow's veil trembles in midnight breeze,
her grief a private planet orbiting darkness.
We bury more than flesh tonight—
buried too: his favorite coffee mug,
unfinished crossword puzzles,
the way he whistled off-key in showers.
Night absorbs our rituals,
this velvet shroud stitching closed
the raw edge between breathing
and becoming memory.

No moon attends this secret burial.
We slip through graveyard gates like thieves
concealing death beneath night’s heavy cloak.
The deceased requested darkness—
no weeping faces, no sunlit platitudes.
Only crickets chant dirges here,
and roots listen as coffin descends.
Why night? Perhaps he feared light’s judgment
on a life peppered with unswept corners.
Or maybe stars reminded him
of childhood camping trips gone sour.
We shovel quietly, guiltily,
as if hiding evidence.
Soil drinks his remains like spilled wine.
Owl hoots—a lone eulogy.
No headstone will mark this plot;
dawn will find only disturbed earth
and our footprints evaporating
with the dew.

City’s heartbeat fades to distant hum
as funeral cars glide through sleeping blocks.
Death wears midnight velvet tonight.
In backseat, I trace raindrops on glass—
each streak a tributary of grief.
Cemetery gates yawn open;
we enter earth’s dreamless realm.
They lower her casket into void
as fog curls around our ankles
like curious strays.
I recall her laugh—bright brass
against life’s dull percussion.
Now silence.
Someone drops roses; petals bleed
against fresh-dug soil.
Headlights carve tunnels through gloom,
exposing marble angels mid-swoon.
We leave quickly, engines growling.
Night folds over the grave
like origami—precise, final.
I watch darkness stitch closed
the wound we made in the world.

Not human, this procession:
fireflies bear tiny lanterns
escorting fallen oak to burial.
Moss-webbed roots cradle the giant
as beetles drag leaf-shrouds
through moon-dappled undergrowth.
Fungi chant in phosphorescent rings,
their glow the only liturgy
for this arboreal passing.
No tears here—only dew.
Wind combs through branches
playing dirges on hollow trunks.
Earth reclaims what storm relinquished.
By dawn, saplings will stretch
green fingers toward the gap in canopy
where the elder once reigned.
Night’s funeral is tender:
a forest knitting closed its wound
with stars for sutures.

They buried the sun at midnight.
No priests, just us—the graveyard shift
watching stars nail shut the sky’s lid.
We drank lukewarm coffee from thermoses
as backhoes bit into twilight.
Lowered the blazing corpse in lead-lined crate
(did you feel that tremor underground?).
No hymns—just radio static
crackling from idling trucks.
We covered day’s coffin with concrete;
poured shadows into the fracture.
Now perpetual night spreads its wings.
Headlights sweep empty streets—
searching for what we interred.
Sometimes at dusk, I swear
I see cracks in western clouds:
gold bleeding through night’s black bandage.
But we keep shoveling darkness,
terrified of dawn’s autopsy.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

text.response:
Dust devils waltz through Karteh-Seh streets,
carrying whispers of Parwan winds. The radio crackles:
"Sunrise at 5:43 AM, high of 32°C, chance of mortar shells
in western districts." Grandmothers trace humidity
on windowpanes like battle maps, while boys kick
soccer balls through sudden downpours that erase
chalk goal lines. At Chicken Street, vendors hawk
saffron-scented sunlight by the gram. Tonight,
the moon will hang like an unexploded ordnance
over Shahr-e-Naw, and stars will pierce the smog
like needlework on burqas. The mountains hold
their breath until dawn, when frost will etch
Pashto verses on military jeeps. We measure time
in monsoons and droughts, praying for clouds
that don't taste of gunpowder. Tomorrow's forecast:
scattered resilience with 100% chance of survival.

Kabul sky wears a patchwork cloak:
indigo at dawn, ash-gray by noon, crimson at dusk.
The muezzin's call tangles with thunder
as laundry lines flap like surrender flags.
Children chart cloud-animals—tank becomes dragon,
apache helicopter morphs to dove. In gardens,
apricot blossoms mistake December warmth
for spring, only to freeze in betrayal. Old men
at Choykhana sip jasmine tea, reading omens
in tea leaves: "See this dark cluster? Rain
will arrive Thursday with American aid trucks."
The river Kabul shrinks to a silver thread,
stitching together broken bridges. Tonight,
winds will carry wedding drums from Wazir Akbar Khan
and gunpowder from Paghman. Forecast says:
"Sunny with afternoon regrets. Highs of hope,
lows of memory. Bring an umbrella
for unexpected grace."

Digital thermometers blink 17°C
but the city's fever runs deeper. Satellite images
show cumulus crowds gathering over the palace ruins,
while ground sensors report tremors
from buried landmines weeping. Street dogs
predict earthquakes by howling at static-filled radios.
At the bazaar, snow globes containing miniature
Buddhas are hawked beside Taliban-era barometers.
Women decipher humidity in the ache
of arthritic knees, men read war scars
like isobars. The meteorological department
issues coded warnings: "Orange alert for nostalgia
when westerlies bring Herati rose scent.
Purple alert for siroccos carrying Persian
love poems." We've learned to interpret
hail as applause from ghost audiences. Forecast:
"Unstable fronts colliding. Carry mendicant's bowl
for collecting rain and shrapnel."

Mountains scribble cirrus messages
in languages only hawks understand. City pigeons
mistake drone hums for thunder, scattering
in panic formations. The weathergirl's chiffon scarf
flutters like a surrender flag as she gestures
at animated clouds: "This front brings monsoons
from the Indus Valley, possibly carrying
forgotten cricket balls and refugee songs."
Farmers near Bagram decode soil cracks
like oracle bones—"Deep fissures mean
Russian tanks will rust faster this spring."
We plant tulips in tank tread grooves, water them
with monsoons and tear gas residue. Tonight,
auroras will dance behind closed curtains
as generators fail. Official forecast:
"Sunrise: 6:02 AM. Sunset: 7:14 PM.
Probability of peace: 0.03%. Chance
of children flying kites in minefields: 67%.
Carry hope. It weighs less than a Kalashnikov."

Dawn breaks like an egg over the Hindu Kush,
yolk spilling on minarets. Barometric pressure
plummets as wedding processions collide
with funeral marches on Flower Street.
Tea-shop philosophers predict monsoons
by counting scorpions in dry wells. The wind
smuggles Persian ghazals through bullet holes
in museum walls. At the airport, departure boards
flash temperature codes only exiles comprehend:
"32°C: mother's lullaby still audible.
-5°C: father's grave unvisited." Street cats
seek shelter in Soviet tank husks when hailstones
bearing Quranic verses fall. Radio static
becomes a prayer rug for the deaf. Tomorrow's
outlook: "Sandstorms may erase national borders.
Frost will preserve graffiti on prison walls.
Carry a spoon to dig for water table dreams.
Survival chance: monsoons divided by regret.
Bring poetry as flotation device."

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

text.response: The radio crackles static, then a voice begins to speak of highs and lows in Kabul, mountain-peak to dusty street. Dawn arrives with powdered light on Hindu Kush's crown, while merchants shake their rugs out in the sleepy, waking town. The announcer speaks of sunshine but forgets to mention how the wind will carry cooking smoke through every alley now. A sudden shower's hinted—just enough to lift the grime that coats the ancient city walls, unchanged by war or time. The forecast doesn't tell you how the afternoon heat weighs like stones in market baskets through the crowded vendor's maze. Nor how the evening chill descends with stars like scattered salt, while families huddle close around a samovar's cobalt halt. The broadcast ends abruptly—just degrees and percentages—while Kabul breathes its own forecast in elemental stances.

They say today in Kabul the wind will sing through ruins, carrying ghosts of minarets in its dry, papery tune. The sun's predicted harshly—a relentless, blazing disk that turns the Kabul River stones to pottery and risk. No mention of the kites though—how they'll dance above the roofs like prayers released from children's hands, defying weather proofs. The forecast might warn of sandstorms rolling in from western plains, but not how mothers shield their eyes from grief's recurring rains. Tonight's low will be bitter, but the numbers never show how elders wrap thin shawls tight against the spectral snow. Tomorrow's chart shows clear skies, yet omits the subtle trace of gunpowder still hanging in this wounded city's space. Kabul's weather writes its own report in ash and stubborn bloom—a forecast etched in resilience against encroaching gloom.

On rooftops, satellite dishes tilt toward foreign skies, translating coded numbers into Kabul's daily guise. 'Partly cloudy'—such strange words for dust that chokes the air, where sunlight filters amber through particulate despair. The temperature is rising, but the real heat hides below in cellars where old radios replay decades of sorrow. Humidity at 15%—too dry for tears to fall, yet women knead the morning dough against the kitchen wall. A 10% chance of rainfall means cracked earth remains unsoothed, while politicians far away discuss our drought as 'proof'. The wind speed isn't measured by anemometers alone, but by how tattered curtains flutter in abandoned homes. Tonight's projected coolness brings no comfort to the street where children count the stars like crumbs of unattainable sweets. This forecast is a fiction penned by satellites above—Kabul's true climate pulses in its people's fears and love.

Kabul doesn't need thermometers to gauge the rising heat—just watch the poplar shadows shrink beneath the noonday street. The mountains are our barometers: when mist hugs Shir Darwaza, expect the scent of wet pine needles drifting through the bazaar. Our forecast's in the market—see the apricot vendor's pile? Bright orange means the summer sun will linger for a while. When swallows skim the rooftops low before the evening prayer, we know tomorrow's winds will sweep the alleys clean and bare. The baker's oven crackling tells more than humidity—his embers glow like sunset when the air grows thick and free. We read the sky in textures: wool-clouds mean the snows will pass, but mare's-tail wisps foretell the tanks will roll through Kote Sangi. Children trace tomorrow's weather in the cracks along the walls—their fingers chart the future where the meteorology falls. Our forecast lives in bone-dust and the rustle of chadors—Kabul breathes its microclimate through a thousand open doors.

Forget the numbers, stranger. Let me tell you how it feels: Kabul's weather moves in colors, not what satellites reveal. Morning arrives as silver—light on bullet-pocked concrete, then shifts to stubborn saffron in the market's buzzing heat. Afternoon is ochre, heavy as the laden carts that creak through streets where shattered windows hold the sky in broken art. Evening turns to indigo, a velvet dark and deep where generators cough like watchdogs while the city tries to sleep. Midnight's shade is charcoal—punctured by a muezzin's cry that rises like a sudden flare against the starless sky. Dawn breaks pale as ash then, but with edges raw and gold—a promise worn and fragile in the mountain's ancient hold. Our forecast has no percentages for hope or for despair, just daily transformations in this thin and vibrant air. Each shift of light and shadow writes a truth no chart can hold—Kabul's climate lives inside us, brave and terribly old.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

text.response:
The radio crackles with static and dust,
Kabul's skyline wears a cloak of rust.
Mountains stand guard in ashen hue,
anticipating skies of forgotten blue.
The muezzin's call weaves through the breeze,
carrying whispers from leafless trees.
Today's forecast: uncertainty's reign,
monsoon dreams drowned in acid rain.
Merchants squint at mercury's lie,
while kites on rooftops scrape the sky.
A sudden gust scatters market wares—
cardamom, sorrows, unspoken prayers.
The mountains swallow the setting sun,
promising snow when the day is done.
But dawn may bring artillery thunder
splitting the clouds asunder.
This city breathes in fractured sighs,
its weather written in children's eyes:
not in degrees or pressure charts,
but resilience stitched in broken hearts.

Beneath the apricot tree's weary shade,
an old man consults the heavens made
of ash and hope. Kabul's forecast scrolls
in patterns only mountains know—
a shift in wind, a vulture's glide,
the scent of snow where snipers hide.
He counts the clouds like rosary beads:
cumulus shadows where conflict breeds,
nimbus warnings in twilight's stain.
His grandson asks, "Will it rain?"
The answer hangs in diesel air,
between bomb craters, deep and bare.
They speak of temperatures that climb
while frost still grips the hands of time.
The forecast? Dust that never settles,
winds that carry wartime metals,
and sunsets bleeding into streets
where bitter cold and anguish meets.
No satellite maps this atmosphere—
just ghosts predicting next year's fear.

Digital screens blink: "Kabul: 9°C."
Outside, reality paints differently—
a woman's chador snaps like war-torn sails,
her basket holds the day's forecast: bread, not gales.
The mountains wear hazy crowns of snow
while market stalls sell warmth below.
A vendor roasts corn over flames that twist,
his weathervane—a child's clenched fist
pointing where Russian tanks once froze.
Now satellites track what wind discloses:
dust devils waltzing through checkpoint lines,
monsoon promises in tangled wires.
The radio warns of coming chill,
but refugees know forecasts lie still—
their barometers are aching bones,
their almanacs etched in gravestones.
Kabul's climate defies prediction:
a sudden blast becomes the friction
that heats the air. The only certainty?
Horizons blurred by tears and tea.

Morning: the sun unveils her face
through smog that veils this wounded place.
The forecast claims "clear skies ahead"
while mortar smoke stains daylight red.
Pigeons wheel in thermal drafts,
above the ruins and broken rafts
of laundry fluttering—white flags
against skies where thunder lags
behind man-made storms. A widow reads
the wind by how her scarves recede
from alleys smelling of damp and fear.
"Spring will come," they said last year.
Now autumn lingers, sharp and thin,
scratching windows with frosty skin.
Meteorologists chart pressure drops
as children chase bomb-scare props—
tin can kites on fraying string,
their laughter warmer than anything
this climate yields. The mountains sigh,
holding blizzards in their eye.
Tonight, the stars won't show their map;
the city dons its thunderwrap.

Kabul's weather: a poet's riddle—
winter's bite in spring's warm middle.
Dawn arrives with silver frost
on tanks where summer heat was lost.
The forecast scrolls in Farsi script:
"Winds from north, with guns equipped."
Farmers study stubborn soil
where snow and shrapnel jointly toil.
A girl counts raindrops on the glass:
each one a memory, fragile, passing.
Her father scans the radio band
for storms descending on the land.
Outside, the sky bleeds sunset gold
over streets where stories go untold.
The mountains whisper to the moon
of blizzards coming all too soon.
But in the bazaar, the tea-stall sage
predicts sunshine on the next war's stage.
This city's climate lives in bones—
not barometers or weather stones—
in grandmothers who feel the air
and know which ghosts are stirring there.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

text.response:
Weather Forecast in Kabul:

The radio crackles static, a dry-throated sigh
as mountains brace for winds that twist and cry.
No rain predicted, just the sun's fierce stare
on streets where dust-devils dance in thin air.

Poppies bow low in fields of brittle gold,
their scarlet heads too weary to unfold
beneath a sky that bleaches every hue.
The kites? Grounded. No breeze to chase the blue.

Old men sip chai, their faces canyon-deep,
recalling springs when snowmelt used to leap
down Paghman's slopes. Now, satellites report
just haze and heat – the arid, blunt retort
of summer's fist. At dusk, a sudden chill:
shrapnel clouds ignite above the hill.

We measure time in gusts: the westward blow
that sweeps the bazaar empty. Watch it go -
a phantom carrying whispers, grit, and dread
past bullet-pocked walls where children tread
barefoot on earth too cracked to sprout a seed.
Tomorrow's high: the same. No sign, no need
for umbrellas here. Just sun-bleached prayers
and nightfall's starless, unforecasted tears.

Weather Forecast in Kabul:

No Doppler radar maps these jagged skies,
just crows that wheel in thermal-lifted lies.
The forecast? Written in the alley's grime:
a stray dog pants in meterological time.

Mercury climbs like rockets in July,
while women beat rugs where the dust flies high
as prophecies. The mountains hold their snow
like secrets. Satellite images show

nothing but static – interference, maybe,
or ghosts of storms too tired to be hazy.
The wind speaks Dari through the pines at noon:
"Expect no rain until the next new moon."

We measure pressure by the ache in bones
of elders watching parched, unyielding stones.
At checkpoints, soldiers squint at sun-blind steel -
the only clouds are ones the convoys feel.

Tonight: a breeze will steal through window bars,
carrying jasmine scent from crater scars.
No precipitation. Just the slow exhale
of land that's memorized drought like a tale.

Weather Forecast in Kabul:

Forget the percentages. Here, weather wears
the face of history. The torrid air
bears shrapnel weight. Each gust recalls the flight
of helicopters through the ashen night.

Pine trees on hillsides whisper coded scripts
of coming frost – how winter slowly strips
the vineyards bare. But satellites can't trace
the microclimate of a widow's face.

Barometer? The market scales that sway
beneath brass weights predicting bread's decay.
The radio announcer clears his throat:
"Sunrise at 6. No coats. No boats. No hope."

We read the winds by laundry lines: a shirt
snaps taut like sails – means western fronts assert
their dusty rule. A kite string snaps mid-air?
That's pressure dropping everywhere.

No fog predicted, just the phantom steam
from samovars in shattered homes that dream
of snow. The forecast map shows endless blue -
an empty grid where nothing moves. Nothing true.

Weather Forecast in Kabul:

Today: relentless sun. The kind that grills
the pavement till it breathes forgotten kills
of rusted metal. Heat-shimmers pretend
to be cool rivers. This is not the end
of drought.

Tomorrow: wind from southern plains
will scour the hills. Expect particulate rains
of powdered brick – the architecture's ghost.
Wear scarves. The airborne past will hurtle most
around 3 PM.

Thursday brings a shift:
a high-pressure ridge (like treaties meant to lift
but crush instead). No clouds. Just bleached regret.
The mountains won't release their snows. Not yet.

Friday? Perhaps a thunderstorm. The kind
that lights the Shomali with rage, designed
to flood the wadis. Lightning will expose
the NATO bunkers where the poppy grows.

Weekend outlook: stable. Clear and dry.
The kind of weather making children cry
for puddles. Old men scan the brittle sky -
their eyes are barometers. No reply.

Weather Forecast in Kabul:

The sky's a shattered mirror. Forecasts fail
where satellites see atmospheric grail
but miss the human tremor in the heat -
the way a beggar's shadow marks the street
as sundial.

Predictions? Mostly dust
and glare. The Kabul River's phantom trust
in rain now just a cracked cement ravine.
The wind instruments record what's unseen:

A scrap of burqa flutters – pressure low.
A vendor's scale tips – high fronts start to blow.
At dawn, the muezzin's cry hangs thick and dry -
no humidity. Just faith against the sky.

Tonight: the stars won't show. Not from the smoke
of cooking fires where hungry families choke
on air as thin as promises. The moon?
A smudged fingerprint on darkness. Soon,

before the sun reheats the shattered glass,
a chill will settle. This too shall pass,
says no one. Frost like ash on twisted beams.
The forecast? Static. Frozen childhood dreams.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

text.response:
Kabul sky, a parchment torn,
Where wind-carved mountains greet the dawn.
The radio crackles, static-torn:
"Dust will rise where rivers mourn,
A dry kiss on the withered corn."

Women trace the window's chill,
Counting clouds above the hill
That once ran green with April's spill.
Now satellites scan, precise and still,
Predicting storms the earth can't feel.

Barometers blink red with fear
As phantom snows appear, disappear
In digital screens. The atmosphere
Holds secrets no forecast can clear:
Tomorrow's sun might scorch, or disappear.

Beneath the minaret's slender shade,
The muezzin's call and the wind's tirade
Collide. The forecast: "Heat will climb
Like prayer towers marking time."

Vendors unfold their patchwork tents,
Squinting at sun with discontent
While children chase the dust-devils' dance.
The dry riverbed, a stark expanse,
Whispers of monsoons lost to chance.

In tea shops, elders sip and sigh,
"No rain will come," the old man's cry.
The mountains wear a hazy shroud
As temperature climbs, fierce and proud.
Kabul waits beneath a sunlit shroud.

The meteorologist's map unfolds
In blues and reds, a tale it holds
Of pressure zones and jet stream lines
That sketch predictions, bold designs
Across Kabul's ancient mountain spines.

But what device can truly gauge
The widow sweeping sorrow's rage
From doorsteps? What algorithm knows
The way a blossom fights and grows
Through cracked cement where no water flows?

Forecasts speak of wind and dust,
Of highs and lows in graphs we trust,
Yet miss the scent of baking bread
That rides the breeze instead,
Or how the stars comfort the dead.

At dawn, the mountains blush with cold,
A frosty breath the foothills hold.
The radio warns: "Sun will blaze
By noon, erase the morning's haze."

In alleys where the shadows sleep,
The forecast makes the beggars weep
For promised rains that never fall.
The sky's indifference covers all—
A dome of blue, imperial, tall.

Beneath it, kites like fragile dreams
Tug at their strings in hopeful streams,
Defying winds the satellites track.
Each thread a lifeline, thin and black,
Holding heaven's mercy back.

Kabul's sky, a poet's page,
Where sun and storm forever wage
Their silent war. The forecast scrolls:
"Brisk winds will test the fragile poles
That hold the tents where hope consoles."

Children memorize cloud formations
Like secret, ancient incantations
Against the drought. The earth, stone-dry,
Absorbs the sun's relentless cry.
No satellite can measure why

A mother scans the western rim
Where thunderheads might gather, dim
And distant. In her cupped hand waits
The phantom weight of rain that fates
Deny. The forecast hesitates.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

text.response:
Over Kabul’s dust-veiled streets, the radio crackles:
*Clouds gather like hesitant promises.*
Merchants unfold rugs beneath apricot skies,
watching cumulus mountains drift past minarets.
Children chase paper kites through alleys
where wind carries whispers of snowfall on Hindu Kush.

At dawn, the baker gauges heat by touch—
flames lick oven bricks, his thermometer broken.
Women read tea leaves in porcelain cups,
tracing storm patterns in bitter swirls.
No satellite maps their intuition:
when swallows dive low, rain arrives by afternoon.

By the Kabul River, dry stones dream of torrents.
Farmers bend over wheat fields, squinting at horizons
where heat shimmers dance with phantom rain.
The forecast is a lexicon of longing:
*Scattered showers*—a rumor from the north;
*Clear nights*—a blanket stitched with stars.

In bazaars, men debate barometric truths
while sparrows announce the only certainty:
tomorrow’s wind will smell of pine and gunpowder,
carrying forecasts written in ash and pollen.

Kabul’s weather is a prisoner’s sketchbook:
Sunflowers tilt behind razor-wire walls.
July bakes mud bricks into terracotta,
but winter? Winter is a knife on skin.

Forecasters speak in cautious metaphors:
*High pressure*—meaning rockets won’t fly tonight;
*Fog*—meaning ghosts walk the Darulaman Road.
The city holds its breath beneath jet trails,
counting seconds between flash and thunder.

On flat rooftops, laundry becomes semaphore:
Shirts wave white flags at reconnaissance clouds.
Pomegranate trees shed crimson prophecies
while elders tap barometers like unexploded ordnance.

Somewhere, a girl charts monsoons in her diary,
inking circles around monochrome radar blips.
Her brother memorizes cloud formations:
*Cumulonimbus* means hiding in basements;
*Cirrus* means hope evaporating westward.

The official report? *Mostly sunny with chance of debris.*
Kabul measures climate in scars per square mile.

Consider the forecast as love letter:
*Darling, expect cumulus by noon—
fluffy as the qabili pulao we shared
near Chicken Street. Tonight, Venus will pierce
the smog like your laughter through gunfire.*

Or as elegy:
*Unseasonal hail crushed the almond blossoms—
white petals now pave Massoud’s grave.*

The meteorologist’s voice cracks
over static: *Temperature inversion…*
(meaning the city chokes on its own breath)
*UV index extreme…*
(meaning our shadows burn faster than we do)

Radio waves warp past Shahr-e Naw,
where neon signs flicker like faulty omens.
A boy sells plastic windmills that spin
only when convoys stir the dust.

Kabul’s climate defies prediction:
One hour, jasmine perfumes artillery smoke;
the next, sirens wail like desert winds.
The truest forecast? A single line:
*Carry an umbrella for ash or grace.*

At the weather station, instruments lie.
Thermometers remember Soviet winters;
anemometers flinch at helicopter downdrafts.
The satellite dish points skyward like a beggar’s bowl.

Outside, kites duel above bullet-pocked walls—
their strings taut as isobars on digital maps.
An old man reads clouds like palm lines:
*See that cirrus? Thin as a refugee’s tent.*

Women on buses touch window fog,
drawing temporary rivers across dusty glass.
They know monsoons by knee ache,
know blizzards by how coal smoke clings to scarves.

Boys kick a ball through sudden rain,
sliding in mud that smells of iron and apricot.
The forecast scrolls on TV screens:
*Precipitation: 40% chance of nostalgia.*

Meanwhile, mountains hoard glaciers like state secrets,
and the wind writes tomorrow’s report
in Braille on skin, in grit on teeth,
in the way sparrows fall silent before rockets rise.

Today’s forecast: *Sunrise at 5:47 AM—
a blade slicing horizon’s bandage.*
Dawn spills over Shahr-e Naw,
gilding broken fountains where sparrows bathe.

*UV index: 9.* Meaning:
Wear your trauma like sunscreen.
Hide memories beneath wide-brimmed hats.

*Afternoon winds: 25 km/h from the west.*
They’ll carry balled poems from girls’ schools,
torn lottery tickets, phosphorus traces.

*Evening: Clear.* But stars here
are surveillance drones or lost ancestors—
depends who watches from the roof.

*Chance of rain: 10%*
(equal to chance of ceasefire)
(equal to chance the phone rings
with a voice from Mazar-i-Sharif)

Midnight: Dry lightning over Paghman.
A boy counts seconds between flash and thunder,
calculating distances to impacts
like futures. The barometer’s needle trembles—
*Pressure dropping.* Always dropping.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

text.response:
Loss can be good for us, the wise declare,
A pruning knife that trims what we hold dear.
When cherished dreams dissolve like morning mist,
We find the structure that we might have missed.
The fallen leaves that blanket autumn's floor
Make space for saplings reaching to explore
New sunlight where old branches once held sway.
What seems like night may herald brighter day.
Our hands release what anchored us too fast,
Discovering what truly comes to last.
The empty chair where laughter used to ring
Teaches new songs the future days will sing.
For every void creates a hollow space
Where wisdom plants its slow, deliberate grace.

Consider winter's stark and barren trees:
Their loss of green reveals strong symmetries
Unseen when foliage masked each graceful line.
So human loss, though bitter as cheap wine,
Strips comforts that obscured our truest form.
We stand revealed before the coming storm
With nothing left to buffer or defend,
Discovering strengths we couldn't comprehend
When cushioned by possessions, love, or place.
The void becomes a crucible of grace
Where character is forged in fires hot.
What seems destruction clears the tangled plot
For seeds of transformation, deep and slow,
That only empty earth permits to grow.

I lost the map that charted my life's course,
And stumbled through thick woods without resource,
Yet in that wilderness of doubt and fear,
New constellations started to appear.
The compass I had clung to proved untrue,
But starlight pierced where sunlight never knew
To reach the forest floor. How strange to find
That being lost expanded heart and mind!
When all familiar landmarks fell away,
My inner landscape brightened in the gray.
Each loss became a guidepost in disguise,
A teacher with unorthodox supplies
That stripped away the nonessential things
And gave me freedom's unexpected wings.

The sculptor's chisel chips the marble block,
Removing chunks with unexpected shock
To free the figure sleeping in the stone.
So loss removes what isn't fully grown
Or true to our essential, core design.
Each fracture shapes a more authentic line,
Each grief-carved groove reveals what must remain.
We shed illusions like the summer rain
That washes dust to show the leaf's true green.
What seems destruction crafts a deeper scene
Where brokenness lets in surprising light
And carved-out spaces make our spirit bright
Enough to hold what matters in the end -
Both what we lose and what we gain, my friend.

You think your heart cannot withstand the tear,
That absence is a weight too great to bear.
But watch the shoreline when the tide recedes:
The treasures buried there are life's new seeds.
What waves erase reveals what lay below -
Patterns in sand that only emptiness can show.
So too when love departs or fortunes fade,
The soul's topography is newly made
Visible in the contours left behind.
The hollows fill with treasures unaligned
With former dreams. This emptying, this pain,
Creates a vessel that can hold the rain
Of unexpected blessings yet to pour.
What's taken opens an unguarded door.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

text.response:
Loss can be good for us,
Like winter's bite that strips the oak,
Revealing bones against the sky.
What falls away makes space to breathe,
A hollow where new seeds may grow.

We clutch our treasures, tight and tense,
Till life's great hand uncurls our grip -
The shattered vase, the job that fled,
The love that slipped like sand through cracks.
At first, the void seems cruel and vast,
A landscape scorched by grief's harsh wind.

But in that clearing, light pours in
Where branches thick once blocked the sun.
We find our spines grow straight and strong
When props are swept away by time.
The empty cradle, quiet now,
Teaches arms to hold the world.

What's lost becomes the fertile ground
Where wiser selves take root and rise -
For every leaf the storm tears free,
A deeper root digs toward the core.
So let the old illusions fall:
Loss sculpts the soul's true architecture.

They say loss carves the canyon deep,
That rivers of regret in time
Will polish stones to gleaming gems.
When farewells hang like stormclouds low,
We learn to dance in sudden rain.

Recall the childhood blanket, frayed -
Its comforting embrace outgrown -
That first release prepares the heart
For greater leavings yet to come.
The empty chair at holiday feasts
Becomes a space for memories
To gather round in golden light.

What's torn away reveals the weave
That holds our fragile lives intact.
The friend who moved across the seas
Left friendship's essence purified.
Even the dreams that turned to dust
Fertilize the waking world.

So let the tides of loss recede -
They leave behind bright seashells
Of resilience on the shore.
For what remains when all seems gone
Is our unadorned, essential core.

Consider how the forest thrives:
The fallen giant, moss-clad, still,
Nourishes the sapling's rise.
Rot becomes rich humus where
New roots embrace decaying wood.

So too with us. The vanished things -
The youth, the chances, loves outlived -
Compost the soil of character.
That promotion lost? It freed your hands
To grasp an unexpected art.

The friend who drifted from your sphere
Left room for truer bonds to bloom.
Even the crumbled certainty
Of health or plans or solid ground
Teaches balance on shifting stones.

We're mosaics of absences -
Each missing shard defines the shape
Of what remains. The phantom limb
Still maps the contours of our growth.
Embrace the ache: it's chisel stroke
Sculpting wisdom from raw grief.

Loss polishes the soul like wind
Wears sandstone into curves of grace.
Remember when the flood rushed through,
Sweeping all your anchored things?
After the waters ebbed away,
You found foundations solid still.

That broken trust? It scraped away
The varnish of naivety
To show the grain of vigilance.
The missed connection, train departed,
Taught you presence at the platform.

Even mortality's blunt blade -
The parent gone, the hourglass tipped -
Cuts tethers to the trivial.
Suddenly, dew on spiderwebs
Gleams with unbearable beauty.

We're stained-glass windows crafted by
The leaden lines of what we lack.
Each fracture bends the light anew,
Creating patterns unforeseen.
Loss: life's merciless artisan.

Picture the sculptor: marble block
Resists the vision in his mind.
With every hammer-blow that chips
Away the excess, form emerges.
So loss removes what isn't us.

That failed endeavor, crumpled plans -
They were ill-fitting costumes dropped.
The shattered dream's sharp fragments
Become mirrors to show your face
Unadorned by wishful thinking.

When possessions whirlwind away
In fire or flood or reckless theft,
You meet your self stripped bare of props -
Discover strength in nakedness.

Even the love that turned to ash
Reveals your heart's undying flame
That burns when fuel is gone.
Embrace the void: it's crucible
Where base attachments turn to gold.
For only through what's torn away
Do we become authentic ghosts
Haunting our own true lives at last.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

text.response:
Loss scrapes the soul raw,
a winter branch stripped bare,
yet in that emptiness
light finds its way through.
When the storm took my oak,
I wept for fallen giants,
but saplings soon unfurled
where shadow once prevailed.

Grief carved hollows deep
where compassion now resides;
when love departed,
I learned to hold space
for others' breaking.
What shatters makes room
for unexpected blossoms -
after the flood recedes,
fertile silt remains.

Letting go of anchors
set my drifting heart free;
when maps burned away,
I discovered stars.
Loss teaches the soil
how to nourish rebirth -
for every fallen petal,
a root digs deeper.

They say loss is the chisel
that sculpts resilience.
When bankruptcy claimed
the empire I had built,
I found liberation
in my empty pockets -
no ledger to constrain
my soul's true currency.

Farewell to false securities!
The crutch of comfort snapped,
forcing my spirit to stand
on unvarnished truth.
Like forests needing fire
to clear deadwood away,
we require devastation
for primordial growth.

Now I tend the garden
of intentional absence,
planting seeds in spaces
where possessions once choked.
The void becomes cathedral -
hollowed ground where wisdom
whispers through the cracks
of broken certainties.

Consider autumn's surrender:
how trees release their glory
without lamentation.
Crimson leaves descend
like discarded poems,
making space for spring's
unwritten verses.

I lost my compass once
in wilderness unknown,
and there discovered
constellations hidden
by city-light pollution.
When familiar paths dissolved,
my feet remembered ancient
ways of navigation.

Loss strips the varnish
from life's furniture,
revealing weathered grain
beneath superficial shine.
What seems cruel subtraction
often proves the equation
needed for balance -
the counterweight that lifts
our weighted spirits
closer to grace.

After the divorce papers
settled like cold ash,
I tasted solitude's
strange vintage.
Empty rooms amplified
echoes of my laughter -
a sound long forgotten
beneath marital noise.

Loss excavated chambers
where new loves might dwell.
The dismantling of dreams
became foundation stones
for unexpected architectures.
Like pottery shattered
and reassembled with gold,
my fractures now gleam
with hard-earned light.

Let us not curse endings
that prune dead branches.
The vine grows stronger
when we dare to cut.
For in life's garden,
compost feeds revival -
from decay springs
the greenest resurrection.

Remember how darkness
nurtures astronomers?
So loss grants vision
unattainable in glare.
When illness claimed
years from my timeline,
I discovered timelessness
in suspended moments.

What slips through fingers
often leaves behind
the gold dust of presence.
That job termination
detonated walls
containing my artistry -
now creativity flows
through liberated cracks.

Even nostalgia's museum
must occasionally purge
exhibits to make space
for fresh interpretations.
Loss is life's curator,
removing the obsolete
so contemporary wonders
may command attention.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

text.response:
Loss can be good for us,
the gardener whispers to the rose
as petals drift like wounded vows.
What falls makes room for greenest growth—
a vacancy where light may dwell,
where tangled roots drink deeper still.
The barren branch, the empty shelf,
the quiet left when love departs
become the hollows where new art
begins to hum. We shed to swell.

When the forest burned to cinder-ash,
charred trunks stood like broken teeth.
Yet in that scorched and silent crash,
seeds cracked open underneath.
Loss can be good for us, they say—
a brutal gift that clears the way
for sunlight through the canopy,
for saplings rising fierce and free.
What fire takes, it gives in space:
room for rebirth's raw embrace.

She held the shards of shattered vase—
blue porcelain on wooden floor.
Grief washed in like tidal force,
but then... a lightness at the core.
Loss can be good for us, she learned.
That emptiness where patterns burned
now held a curious kind of grace:
a blankness begging for design,
a canvas washed with cleaner line.
She gathered fragments, rearranged,
and from the ruins, beauty changed.

Consider tides abandoning the shore,
leaving stranded shells and drying kelp.
The gulls protest with raucous roar,
yet in retreat, the ocean's help
prepares the sand for castles new.
Loss can be good for us—it's true.
That hollow where the waves withdrew
becomes a playground for the dawn.
What ebbs will flow, what's gone
makes space for footprints not yet drawn.

Memories packed in cardboard graves,
dust motes dancing in the van.
He watched his history drive away,
feeling lighter than he began.
Loss can be good for us, he thought,
weight exchanged for lessons taught.
That phantom limb of ownership
faded to a softer grip.
Now unburdened by the shelves,
he found himself collecting selves.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

text.response:
Loss carves hollows in the soul's terrain,
Where emptiness blooms wisdom's sharpest seed.
It strips the varnish from our polished gain,
Revealing truths we never thought to heed.
When comfort's tapestry begins to fray,
The threads unravel patterns we outgrew -
A bitter harvest clearing space for May,
Where stronger blossoms drink restorative dew.

We clutch at fragments drifting through our hands,
Each shard reflecting what we must release.
The phantom weight of absent wedding bands
Teaches new rhythms as old tensions cease.
Loss sculpts our contours with relentless art -
The chisel's bite reveals the statue's heart.

Through vacant rooms, we learn to walk alone,
Discovering reserves we never knew.
The silence where familiar voices shone
Becomes a crucible forging something new.
What falls away leaves fertile ground behind -
A blankness waiting for the next design.

Consider autumn's necessary crime:
The trees that hemorrhage gold against the sky.
Each falling leaf commits a act of time,
A sacrifice that lets the roots breathe high.
So loss exfoliates our cluttered days,
Sweeping dead wood from life's persistent stream.
What burns away in unexpected blaze
Creates the ash from which new meanings gleam.

We mourn the shoreline swallowed by the tide
Yet find in that retreat a broader view.
Where anchors rusted, currents now can glide -
Expansion blooms in spaces torn from you.
The hollowed trunk becomes a nesting place,
Scarred bark nurturing unexpected grace.

Not emptiness, but vacancy's keen gift -
A blank page fluttering where stories clung.
Release becomes the unexpected lift
That teaches dormant wings how to be young.
What slips beyond our trembling fingertips
Leaves room for constellations in the grip.

They say the forest needs the cleansing fire,
That charred earth births the sequoia's might.
So loss becomes the crucible's desire,
An alchemy transforming dark to light.
When cherished idols crumble to the ground,
The earthquake shifts foundations we called true.
In rubble, unfamiliar paths are found -
Strange constellations pierce the broken view.

Recall the oyster wounded by the grain:
That irritation builds the pearl's embrace.
Our deepest fractures channel healing rain,
Creating reservoirs in empty space.
What vanishes leaves fingerprints behind -
Blueprints for bridges we were meant to design.

Grief's erosion carves canyons in the soul,
Exposing layers time had safely veiled.
The missing pieces make the puzzle whole
By showing where our edges have impaled
New possibilities against the shore -
What recedes creates the space for more.

Imagine rivers changing course by force -
The old bed drying under startled sun.
At first, just absence marks the vanished source,
Until new tributaries are begun.
So loss redirects life's stubborn flow,
Scraping the channels where our habits ran.
The emptiness we struggle to forgo
Becomes the birthplace of a different plan.

We clutch the photographs until they fade,
While present moments slip between our hands.
But vacancy becomes the cleanest blade -
It pares existence to essential strands.
What's taken leaves an unplanned aperture:
Strange light floods through the unexpected door.

Like pruned vines bleeding sap beneath the knife,
We feel the cut that seems like pure defeat.
Yet dormant buds awaken into life
From nodes where absence made the structure neat.
The sculpture needs the marble's sacrifice -
Release reveals the form within the ice.

After the avalanche, the mountain shows
New contours hidden under heavy snow.
What crashed away releases ancient stone -
A different beauty in the afterglow.
So loss scrapes clean our calcified designs,
Exposing bedrock where illusions lay.
The empty spaces birth unplanned lines -
Frescoes emerging where old murals fray.

We trace the ghosts of what we thought we owned:
That favorite teacup shattered on the floor,
The love letters that somehow were disowned -
Their absence writes new legends to explore.
The hollows in our chests become wind chimes,
Catching new music in the drafts of time.

What falls away creates a silent bell
Whose ringing shapes the architecture here.
Each farewell carves an unexpected well
Where deeper waters than we knew appear.
The phantom limbs still tingle in the night,
But dawn reveals what's gained in missing's light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

text.response:
Loss carves hollows where new rivers run,
Scouring channels for tomorrow's sun.
We clutch at fragments - photographs, a name -
Then find our hands were never meant to claim
The solid permanence we thought we owned.
When cherished ground becomes uncertain, moaned,
We plant fresh roots in unexpected earth.

Grief's chisel chips what childhood deemed true:
That love means holding, safety clings to you.
But broken vessels teach containment's art -
How emptiness makes room for whole new hearts.
That job, that dream, that person gone too soon
Become dark loam where stronger flowers bloom.

We fear the emptying, the silent ache,
Not knowing voids are molds that futures make.
Like winter stripping branches to the bone
Reveals the architecture trees have known,
Our stripped-down seasons show what truly stays -
The unbreakable core that meets the blaze.

Loss isn't thief but stern gardener's knife
That prunes dead wood to cultivate new life.

Consider forests after wildfire's rage -
Blackened spires on a ravaged stage.
Yet in that ash, sun warms the hidden seeds
That wait for ruin to fulfill their needs.
New saplings rise where fallen giants lay,
And phoenix ferns greet ashen, smoky day.

So too with us when treasured things depart:
The burning clears the landscape of the heart.
We water roots we never knew were there,
Discover sunlight in the thinning air.
That lover gone? Now space to know your mind.
That shattered plan? New pathways to unwind.

What perished made room for untried breath -
The quiet liberation after death
Of old assumptions. Emptied hands can hold
Horizons wider than the stories told
By comfort's repetitive refrain.
Loss plows the field where wilder flowers reign.

Don't curse the hollows where your tears collect -
They're cisterns for the rain you didn't expect.

The sculptor knows: to shape the marble's grace
Requires removal. Chisel strikes erase
What hides the angel sleeping in the stone.
Our losses chip away the hardened bone
Of habit, certainty, and easy lies
That cloud the spirit's form before our eyes.

When friendship cools or fortune turns her face,
When trusted pillars vanish without trace,
We stand exposed - but truer for the gale
That stripped pretension like a withered sail.
What broke revealed the unadorned design
Beneath the gilded surface we called mine.

That promotion lost? Now deeper vocation calls.
That faded memory? Truth when illusion falls.
Each absence leaves a negative-space relief
That defines the contours of authentic grief
And joy. The cup must first be emptied, dry,
To taste the vintage waiting in the sky.

Embrace the carving tool that seems so cruel -
It's crafting you a wiser, brighter jewel.

Sailors on becalmed and stagnant seas
Long for the storm that bends the stubborn knees
Of masts to purpose. Stillness breeds decay -
It's shattered sails that catch the wind's wild way.

So loss becomes the tempest we require
To jolt us from the mud of low desire.
That nest emptied by fledglings taking flight?
Now wings expand in unexpected height.
That safe routine that vanished overnight?
Adventure whispers in the sudden light.

We cling to anchors, curse the rising gale,
Not knowing driftwood builds the sturdiest sail.
What's torn away reveals what can't be drowned -
The buoyant self no circumstance has bound.
The lover left? Now oceans to explore.
The shattered vase? New art upon the floor.

Don't fear the shipwreck. From the flotsam, rise -
Salt-crusted, seeing clearer skies.

Observe the canyon: eons of retreat
By patient water carving something sweet
From stubborn rock. The river's slow goodbye
Sculpted cathedral cliffs against the sky.

Such artistry requires surrender's art -
The yielding that remakes a human heart.
When dreams erode like sandstone in the rain,
Their passing leaves surprising new terrain:
Valleys where compassion's rivers flow,
Buttes of resilience we didn't know.

That trust betrayed? It washed illusions clean,
Exposing bedrock where truth stands unseen.
That youthful hope worn smooth by time's harsh flow?
Now wisdom's patterns in the bedrock show.

We curse the current carrying things away
But watch what grandeur forms day after day:
The depth to hold more joy than shallow streams,
The space for sunlight in forgotten seams,
The echo chamber where our laughter rings
With purer notes loss's chiseling brings.

Stand in the gorge loss carved and sing aloud -
Your voice sounds clearer, stripped of every shroud.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Prelude to "Stalky & Co."'

text.response:
The bell tolls bronze across the quad,
A summons sharp as winter air.
Three shadows slip on dew-kissed sod,
A prelude played beyond compare.
Stalky, Beetle, M'Turk conspire
Beneath the ivy's ancient twist,
Where dormer windows catch the fire
Of dawn's first gold in mist.

Their boots scrape flagstones, echoes fly
Through cloisters damp with vanished years,
While masters pace with furrowed eye
And chalkdust ghosts in empty biers.
The scent of ink and linseed oil,
Of rotten apples in the store,
Of mischief bubbling into boil
Behind the oak-panelled door.

A rook caws from the chapel spire,
Watching the trio melt from view
Through secret gaps in barbed wire
Where freedom's wilder breezes blew.
This overture to teenage war
Where rules are bent like sapling trees,
Where lessons learned forevermore
Drift on the Westward breeze.

Before the ink dried on the page,
Before the tales took flight,
There lingered in the storied age
A prelude in the night.
The scrape of desks, the cricket pitch,
The head's stern reprimand,
The secret passage, cobweb-rich,
Beneath forbidden land.

Three hearts that beat as one conspire
Against the gray routine,
Their youthful souls a burning pyre
On Britain's pastoral scene.
The dormitory whispers rise
Like incense to the moon,
While distant farmstead puppy-cries
Tune nature's counter-tune.

Oh, prelude to the coming fray
Of cunning stratagems!
Where boys will outwit masters gray
And fox-like outwit gems
Of discipline. The cricket bat
Shall be Excalibur,
The Latin grammar, tomcat chat
When bounds become a blur.
This overture to comradeship
In Devon's hallowed ground
Sets stage for every friendship
Where loyalty is found.

The gorse blooms gold on Devon hills,
The Channel mists retreat,
As destiny with laughter fills
These halls where legends meet.
A prelude hums in mortar cracks,
In chalk dust motes that dance,
In covert paths and hidden tracks
Where truant feet advance.

Three silhouettes against the dawn
Survey their kingdom small:
The fives court trampled, dew withdrawn,
The study's papered wall
That bears the scars of pellet guns
And smuggled candle wax.
The coming chronicle's first suns
Illuminate the facts
Of boyhood's sacred anarchy
That bends but will not break
'Neath rigid pedagogy's
Demands for virtue's sake.

This overture of scrapes and schemes,
Of inkwells overspilled,
Is woven through with golden gleams
Of promise unfulfilled
By clocks that chime the passing hour.
The prelude holds the key
To doors where adolescent power
Builds immortality.

The Head's black gown, a raven's wing,
Sweeps corridors of oak,
While three small rebels, gathering,
Exchange a secret joke.
The prelude starts with muffled snorts
Behind the chapel screen,
With smuggled tarts and dubious sports
Upon the bowling green.

Old Kipling's pen begins to trace
The contours of the tale:
The smudged young face, the stolen case,
The rabbit in the vale
Of discipline. The dorm's stale air
Thick with conspiracy,
The masters' glares, the boys' cool stare
In sweet anarchy.

This overture to cunning games
Where wits outstrip the cane,
Where no one blames or calls the names
That break the rules again.
The cricket score, the Latin test,
The smuggled bullpup's bark,
All coalesce in manifest
Against the gathering dark
Of adulthood's encroaching pall.
The prelude holds the light
Of boyhood's brief, defiant call
Before it takes its flight.

Before the ink had stained the sheet,
Before the fame accrued,
There came the patter of young feet
On flagstones roughly hewed.
A prelude sung in minor keys
By winds through window cracks,
In buzzing flies and swaying trees
And mortar's hairline cracks.

Three minds that scheme in harmony
Against the common foe
Of dreary Greek and history
Taught ponderously slow.
The scent of gunpowder and soap,
Of bootblack, ink, and fear,
Of adolescent hope
That marks the turning year.

This overture to wild escapades
Through fields of standing corn,
Where memory never fades
Of friendships newly born
In shared detention's gloomy hold,
In midnight feasts suppressed,
In stories yet untold
That swell within the breast.
The chapel bell's bronze tongue now rings
Across the misty downs,
And with each chime the prelude sings
Of laurels, not of crowns.
For here begins the chronicle
Where boyish gods create
Their Valhalla from a dormitory cell
And shape their future state.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Prelude to "Stalky & Co."'

text.response:

With ivy clutching ancient stone,
With whispers, soft as secret sounds,
That boys, not yet quite fully grown,
Would spin rebellion into lore,
And carve their names forevermore.

Not yet the scrape of boot on stair,
Nor challenge flung in studied tones,
Just sunlight shafting, thick with air
Where dust, like memory, still drones.
The prelude breathes the quiet pause,
The lull before the chaos breaks:
The careful plotting without cause,
The laughter that the stillness shakes.
A world confined by brick and rule,
A stage set bare, awaiting art,
Where cunning minds, no master's tool,
Prepare to play their vital part.
Before the clash, the sharp retort,
This hush holds futures, grim and fraught.

Think not of masters, grim and tall,
Nor Latin verbs that twist the tongue,
But of the gap beneath the wall
Where freedom's urgent song is sung.
The prelude thrums with muffled feet,
With stifled giggles in the dark,
With stolen jam, absurdly sweet,
And plans as wild as any spark.
It smells of gunpowder experiments,
Of damp earth dug for treasure hid,
Of youthful, fierce intelligence
Beneath a carefree, larking lid.
This is the soil, both rich and rough,
Where Stalky's clever weeds grew tough.

The old stone schoolhouse, stern and grey,
Stands sentinel in morning mist,
A silent stage before the play
Of boyish anarchy exists.
The prelude whispers in the beams,
In empty desks where ink will stain,
It drifts through classrooms, holds the dreams
Of stratagems devised in vain?
Oh, no! For cunning lies in wait,
Behind the smirk, the casual glance,
To circumvent impending fate
Or seize the fleeting, glorious chance.
Before the first bell tolls the fray,
The spirit learns to disobey.

Forget the cane, the rulebook's weight,
The prelude sings a different tune:
Of comradeship that seals the fate
Of tyrants underneath the moon
(Or study lamp). It speaks of trust
Forged not in blood, but ink and grime,
Of cleverness that turns to dust
The heavy tread of measured time.
It hums the rhythm shared by three,
A synchronicity of thought,
A silent, swift conspiracy
That traps the foe, however taut
The watchful net. Before the strife,
This prelude charts a different life.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Prelude to "Stalky & Co."'

text.response:
Before the ivy claimed these walls of stone,
Where laughter echoes in the corridors alone,
Three shadows dart where prefects seldom peer –
Stalky, M'Turk, and Beetle, pioneers
Of clever chaos. Ink-stained fingers trace
Plans in Latin textbooks, while the commonplace
Lessons drone like bees in drowsy heat.
They'll turn a master's dignity to retreat
With well-placed frogs or subtly altered maps,
While Kipling's pen, with fondness, perhaps,
Recalls the alchemy of boyhood's scheme:
Where chalkdust motes become a rebel's dream.
The Head (half-smiling, half-exasperated)
Knows their mischief forges bonds created
In shared detention's oddly hallowed ground,
Where loyalty and cunning both are found.
This prelude hums with cricket bats and sneers,
The overture to scrappy, vital years.

Oh, whistle-call that cuts the morning grey!
The prelude stirs before the curtain's rise
On dormitory conspiracies and lies
Told with straight-faced grace. The disarray
Of adolescence – raw, unvarnished, bold –
Takes center stage. Here, rules are bought and sold
For favours owed; where honour oddly clings
To secret codes and makeshift, cobbled things.
The scent of linseed oil on cricket pads,
The chalk-slap rhythm every schoolboy had,
The furtive jam-tins passed 'neath desk-lids low –
This is the overture to all we know
Of Stalky's realm. Not grand, but fiercely real,
Where scrapes and scars forge friendships made of steel.
A symphony of scrapes begins to play
In minor keys before the break of day.

The corridors remember boot-scuffed floors,
The ghost of Beetle's ink-smudged, hurried score.
Before the chronicle of plots takes flight,
The prelude gathers mischief in the night.
A dormitory window, cracked ajar,
Reveals the constellations – near, yet far –
While plotting whispers weave a subtle thread
To humble pompous masters in their beds
With pilfered trousers, hung from flagpole heights.
This is the prelude: testing ancient rights,
Proving the system porous, slow, and dense,
Through wit, not fists. A boy's intelligence
Outflanking rules. The school, a stage unlit,
Where heroes aren't the ones who neatly sit,
But those who navigate the grey expanse
With sideways grins and clever circumstance.

Recall the scrape of desks on wooden floors,
The prelude hums beyond the study doors.
Here, Kipling sets his stage with cricket green,
Where Stalky's trio moves, rarely seen
By rule-bound eyes. The masters, stiff and stern,
Are targets for the lessons they must learn
From impudent youth. A smuggled ferret's squeal
Disrupts the sermon, forcing truth to feel
More real than doctrine. This prelude sings
Of pocketed tuck, of catapult-thrown things,
Of boundaries pushed with adolescent glee.
It’s not just mischief – it’s philosophy
In action. How to bend without quite breaking,
How alliances need no oath-taking,
Just shared contempt for arbitrary force.
Here starts the rough, unpolished, vital course.

The bell-tower chimes the prelude's solemn start
To tales of cunning, played with boundless art.
Not epic battles, but a well-aimed snare
For Foxy’s watchful eye. The humid air
Of study hall holds whispers sharp and keen,
Where Latin verbs cloak strategies unseen.
The trio’s bond, a fortress built on trust
Forged in detention, tempered by the dust
Of secret tunnels. Kipling’s prelude shows
The crucible where character first grows –
Not polished virtue, but resourcefulness,
The sharp, pragmatic, irreverent finesse
That scoffs at medals, honours, formal praise.
Their triumphs live in unexpected ways:
Outwitting systems, mocking stale decorum.
This prelude rings – a rough, rebellious chorus.

text.response:

They plot with maps of apple trees

Oh, hear the muffled, stifled cheer!
The glorious chaos drawing near!
This hive of boyhood, sharp and sweet,
Preludes the triumph and defeat.
Before the ink-stained page unfurls,

The lark above the cricket pitch

The chalk dust motes in sunbeam streams
Reveal the fabric of our schemes;
A smuggled cat purrs in the bin,

We navigate the grim decree
Of homework, canes, and misery
With grubby hands and eyes alight—
Small anarchists against the night
Of dull routine. The masters frown,
But we are kings of Upside-Down,
Where honour’s found in clever lies
And truth gleams in a comrade’s eyes.
So let the solemn bell-tower chime—
We’re carving legends out of time.

The scent of rain on playing fields,
The rusted gate that never yields,
The crack of willow striking leather,
Boys bound by wind and weather.
Here’s where the saga takes its root—
In muddied boot and purloined fruit,
In dormitories after dark,
Where whispered plots leave their mark.
A world contained by brick and slate,

Through trials of fire, friendship’s forge,
Against the system’s grinding gorge.
The masters drone like distant bees,
But we are pirates on high seas
Of dusty books and locker raids,

This prelude hums with restless might,
A chrysalis before the flight
Of tales where cunning trumps the cane,
Where losses turn to lifelong gain.
The inkwell waits, the page is bare—
Adventure breathes in the damp air.

Before the first word stains the page,
Before the war of wit and rage,
There lies the hush—the breathless pause—
Where fledgling rebels draft their laws.
The study door is locked with care;
Three heads bent close in secret prayer
To mischief. Beetle’s specs agleam,
Stalky’s grin, a waking dream,
And M’Turk’s quiet, watchful gaze.
The building holds its breath for days
Anticipating their next coup.
The headmaster’s stern voice cuts through
The stillness like a winter bell—
A challenge that they know too well.
This prelude is the gathering storm,
The shaping of the rebel norm
In corridors of oak and stone,
Where boys make kingdoms of their own.
The cricket bat leans by the stair,
A silent sentinel. Beware,
Ye powers-that-be! The game’s afoot—
Watch how the saplings bend the root.

Oh, smell the linseed-oiled bat!
The fusty tomes, the dormouse fat
That sizzles on a stolen stove.
This is the prelude, push and shove
Of boyhood’s raw, unfiltered joy,
Where every scheme’s a Trojan horse

The masters’ wrath? A fleeting cloud.
The code is clear: be bold, be loud
In secret. Let the gas jets hiss
On pages filled with artifice
Of algebra and Greek declensions—
Mere covers for our bold inventions.
The pillow-fight’s percussion beat
Echoes rebellion, sharp and sweet.
Here, honour’s not in hymns or pews,
But how you share contraband brews
Or take the blame to shield your friend.
This prelude has no tidy end—
It spills like ink on blotting paper,
A joyous, messy, boyish caper.
So raise the flag on Fort Despair!

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Hair-raising novelty;'

text.response:
Hair-raising novelty; a shockwave through the mundane,
A jolt that sets the dormant neurons aflame.
Like lightning splitting ancient oak in two,
It cleaves the comfortable, the old, the known in view.

Sudden strangeness prickles on the skin,
A shiver down the spine where new worlds begin.
Uncharted pathways in the brain ignite,
Transforming greyest dusk to blinding light.

A first kiss under unfamiliar stars,
The jagged rhythm of electric guitars
That shreds the silence of a well-worn room,
Or strange perfume that hints of alien bloom.

It screams in neon through the quiet street,
A discordant rhythm, wild and bittersweet.
Hair-raising novelty—both thrill and fright,
A comet tearing through the fabric of the night,
Leaving static sparks where certainty once stood,
And in its wake, the thrilling, trembling good.

Hair-raising novelty; the phrase itself a spark,
Igniting thoughts that wander in the dark.
Consider newborn fawns on wobbly legs,
Or cryptic runes on ancient mossy dregs.

It’s peeling back the bark to find blue veins
In trees that hum with unexpected rains.
Or tasting ice that burns like liquid flame,
A paradox without a single name.

It’s cities built on clouds we walk upon,
Or clockwork birds that sing a vanished dawn.
The frisson when a stranger’s eyes hold yours,
And suddenly, the universe implores:

"Forget the maps you’ve drawn, the paths you’ve trod—
Here be dragons, and the grace of God."
Hair-raising novelty, electric, vast,
A door where solid walls were standing fast.

Hair-raising novelty; a jagged edge,
A precipice, a whispered, wild pledge.
It smells of ozone after summer storms,
Of unread books with unfamiliar forms.

It tastes like metal on the startled tongue,
Like songs in languages not yet been sung.
It feels like vertigo on mountain peaks,
Where gravity’s familiar comfort speaks
No more—just wind and space and falling free.

It sounds like static on a dead TV
That suddenly resolves to alien skies,
Or whale-song coded in galactic sighs.

This prickling awe when old assumptions die,
When stars rearrange in a stranger’s eye,
Is nerve and wonder braided tight as rope—
Hair-raising novelty: defiance, hope.

Hair-raising novelty—not thrill alone,
But roots upturned from comfort’s settled stone.
It’s finding wings upon your shoulder blades,
Or conversing with the ever-shifting shades
That dance in firelight, speaking truths untold,
While frost blooms fractal on the window, bold.

Imagine mushrooms glowing in the gloom,
A silent, bioluminescent bloom
In forests deep where no human has stood,
Rewriting "possible" for understood.

Hair-raising novelty: perpetual change.

Hair-raising novelty; the shock that rends,

Hair-raising novelty, forever changed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Hair-raising novelty;'

text.response:

Hair-raising novelty; the jungle breathed anew—

We thought we'd cataloged each scale and claw,

No hide nor hair for labs to analyze,

Now maps mean nothing. Science holds its breath.

Hair-raising novelty; not in labs or stars,
But when her laugh disrupted prison bars
Of routine. Monday’s grey dissolved like mist
Revealing constellations where her wrist
Turned, brushing mine. The café’s murmur died—

Electric silence bloomed. My world inside
Flipped like a coin mid-toss. Her simple glance
Unlocked dimensions in this trance
Where coffee steam became auroral light,
Her eyelash flutter rewrote day and night.

This wasn’t love—too primal, too untamed—
But atoms singing, newly rearranged.
Her ordinary name now tasted strange,
A rune that made reality derange.

Familiar streets became a mythic maze,
Each brick imbued with unexpected blaze.
The terrifying thrill? This seismic jar
Came not from comet, but a human scar
Reopened by connection’s sudden spark—
The oldest mystery made fresh and stark.

Hair-raising novelty; the theater stage
Unspooled its script. The lead forgot his rage,
Stared past the spotlight into cosmic dark
Where velvet curtains tore. A disembarked

Presence emerged—not ghost, but something raw,
A living equation breaking natural law.
Its form kept shifting: part machine, part root,
Humming a chord that made the audience mute
With dread and wonder. Props dissolved to sand.
Stagehands froze mid-gesture, wands in hand.

The fourth wall didn’t shatter—it caught flame,
Revealing backdrops whispering our true name
In tongues unknown. That actor, pale and still,
Met eyes with raw creation past the skill
Of playwrights. Truth erupted through the art,
Leaving us trembling, clutching chests and heart.

Applause died unborn. We left in silent awe,
Knowing performance held a fatal flaw:
Reality’s an understudy waiting
In wings beyond control, devastating
Our crafted fictions with one glimpse of raw,
Hair-raising novelty beyond encore.

Hair-raising novelty; the archaeologists’ cry
Echoed in canyons where no birds dare fly.
Not bones or pottery—that would be tame—

In alphabets unborn. The structures bent

To challenge angles. Murals showed our sky
With unfamiliar constellations high.

Chronometers embedded in the walls

These towers sang in radio wave choirs,
Ignoring gravity’s exhausted wires.
No burial site this, but sprouting seed

What shocked us most? A child’s handprint, clear,

Or any year we’ve measured. History’s spine

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Hair-raising novelty;'

text.response:

Hair-raising novelty; the attic's gloom

Its chimes like fractured childhood dreams

What clockwork ghost defied decay?

My breath caught sharp on attic air,

Hair-raising novelty; the ocean's roar

Fishermen's cries like splintered glass

That wall of brine, primordial, vast,

We stood transfixed on trembling sand,

When waters calmed, the shoreline changed—

Hair-raising novelty; the newborn's cry

A knowing gaze from wrinkled face

She gripped my thumb with strength untold,

A whispered word—not baby talk—

The midwife crossed herself in fright

Then infant softness washed her clean,

Hair-raising novelty; the forest floor

What mycelial mind awoke?

Hair-raising novelty; the desert sang.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Hair-raising novelty;'

text.response:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Hair-raising novelty;'

text.response:
Hair-raising novelty; a shiver down the spine,

With chaos. Think of footsteps in an empty hall

Failing mid-stride. That gasp when clocks reverse,
When mirrors show not you, but some ancient curse
Or future self. The thrill when stars rearrange

The world unstitched, revealing wonders in the dark.

Hair-raising novelty; that jolt when autumn trees

Novelty bites—a vampire kiss of change—
When clocks sprout lilacs, numbers rearrange

It’s life’s needle skipping grooves, then playing tracks

Hair-raising novelty; like stepping through a door

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss'

text.response:
Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss the twilight air,
Where fireflies weave their drunken trails through lilac-scented hair.
The moon's a silver smirk above the willow's sway,
Go steal the stars from velvet skies and toss them in the bay.

Your laughter cracks the chapel bells, a sacrilege so sweet,
While dew-kissed roses bow their heads to worship at your feet.
That rebel grin could topple thrones or melt a frosty heart,
So dance through vineyards, reckless sprite, and play your wicked part.

Kiss the baker's flour-dusted cheek, the blacksmith's sooty hand,
Kiss truth from politicians' lips in this corrupted land.
Then kiss the crooked garden gate where honeysuckles twine,
And leave your mark on everything – this wild world is thine.

When dawn arrives with prim reproach, all proper, starched, and pale,
You'll curl like smoke against my chest and whisper our betrayal.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss the raven's wing
That sweeps across the graveyard fog where banshees mutter sins.
The mausoleum's chill embrace awaits your trembling lip,
Press devotion on cold stone where mortal passions slip.

Kiss the poison ivy's curl around the crumbling urn,
Kiss the epitaphs that weep for loves they couldn't earn.
Your breath – a ghostly vandal – fogs the names of saintly dead,
While specters coil like incense smoke above your wayward head.

No sweetheart's kiss you offer Death, but fevered, sharp defiance,
A necromantic pact you seal through daring, dark alliance.
The tombstone saints avert their eyes, the reaper drops his scythe,
As you imprint your living heat where all decay must writhe.

At midnight's toll, return to me with grave-dirt on your tongue,
We'll drink the churchyard's silence dry before the matins sung.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss that grumpy cat
Who guards the fishmonger's back door – just see where that gets at!
Then kiss the mayor's shiny pate (he'll turn magenta-red),
And plant one on the parking meter till its lights all flash like mad.

Go kiss the frozen pizza box inside the grocery aisle,
The subway turnstile's rusty mouth – that ought to make it smile!
Kiss every 'Wet Paint' sign you see with mischievous delight,
And blame it on the garden gnomes who party every night.

Now kiss the robot vacuum clean (it beeps in pure surprise),
Then kiss the judge's powdered wig when shutting both your eyes.
Kiss yesterday's discarded socks, kiss algebra's cruel 'X',
Kiss anything absurdly wrong to vex and to perplex.

Return with tales of chaos spun and smirking like a sprite,
We'll toast with pickle juice and laugh into the absurd night.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss the morning fields,
Where poppies nod their drowsy heads and all the earth reveals
Her secrets to your barefoot tread. Kiss sunlight on the wheat,
Kiss raindrops clinging stubbornly to clover at your feet.

Kiss the patient, mossy stones that guard the babbling brook,
Kiss willow fronds that sweep the ground in every cranny nook.
The breeze will tangle in your hair, a lover's whispered sigh,
As you imprint the meadow's cheek beneath the dragonfly.

Kiss cherry blossoms as they fall like pink, confetti snow,
Kiss stubborn dandelion heads where wishes wait to blow.
Let bees become your acolytes, drunk on your nectar touch,
And rabbits pause their thumping hearts to witness overmuch.

Then kiss the sunset's coral blush, the twilight's purple veil,
Before returning home to me, your pockets full of tales
Of how the wild, untamed green world surrendered to your bliss
Beneath that simple, sweet command: 'Go, naughty girl, and kiss.'

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss each memory's sting –
The photograph still trembling from the song you used to sing,
The coffee cup that chipped its rim the day the silence fell,
The empty space beside me where your shadow used to dwell.

Kiss every unanswered text that glows in midnight blue,
Kiss every 'what if' that still haunts the spaces between truths.
Let lips like gentle archaeologists brush dust from buried things,
Excavate forgotten laughter where the hollow echo rings.

Kiss doorknobs that you turned away from, leaving without sound,
Kiss mirrors where your younger self still waits, forever bound.
Imprint forgiveness on the walls that witnessed all our wars,
Kiss cracks along the ceiling where the rain seeped through our flaws.

Then come to me, my bittersweet, with ghosts upon your mouth,
We'll taste the ashes on our tongues – north, south, east, and west.
For every kiss you gave the past becomes a phantom key
To rooms we locked with trembling hands... unlock them now for me.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss'

text.response:

Kiss the dandelion wisps adrift in fading light.
