These meetings carve us, stone on stone,
Like rivers shaping canyon walls,
The seeds of kindness we have sown
In crowded streets or empty halls.
Some pass like comets, wild and brief,
A streak of laughter in the dark,
While others share our joy and grief,
Leaving eternal, precious marks.
So hold each moment, pure and true,
For human threads compose our song,
The many souls we journey through
Make us where we all belong.

We meet many people in life,
A gallery of fleeting art,
The nurse who calms a newborn's strife,
The stranger mending broken hearts.
Some crash like waves upon the sand,
Wild moments burning fierce and fast,
Others with a gentle hand
Guide us home when we're lost at last.
The busker's tune on Wednesday noon,
The soldier sharing battlefield tales,
The crescent moon, the monsoon,
Humanity when all else fails.
These intersections, brief and grand,
Are constellations in our sky,
Each holding out a helping hand
As days and years go drifting by.
So honor every face you see,
For in their eyes whole worlds reside,

With all of humankind allied.

We meet many people in life,

For souls we touch and those who flee

The child laughing wild and free,

So cherish every brief hello,

We meet many people in life,

The taxi driver's radio hum,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My poem may be yours indeed'
Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My poem may be yours indeed'

text.response:
My poem may be yours indeed,
A fragile vessel holding need,
Not born from ink on lonely page,
But whispered through a shared age.
I found it drifting on the breeze,
A ghost of longing through the trees,
Or caught within the city's roar,
A rhythm knocking at your door.
It speaks of joy you almost claimed,
Of quiet sorrows never named,
A truth your hidden heart has kept,
While all around you simply slept.
So take these words, they seek your ear,
Not truly mine, though penned from here.
They resonate within your core,
My poem may be yours, and more.

My poem may be yours indeed,
Not mine to hoard, but yours to seed.
I wove the thread from borrowed light,
From your own laughter, burning bright,
From shadows only you have known,
In whispered secrets, softly sown.
The ache you feel? It fuels my line.
The hope you hold? That pulse is mine.
The rhythm mimics your quick breath,
A mirror held to life and death
As *you* perceive it, sharp and keen.
This verse is merely the lathe between
Your raw experience and the air.
My poem may be yours – take care,
For in its depths, your own soul stares,
Acknowledged, shared, beyond all cares.

My poem may be yours indeed,
A flimsy notion, born of greed
Or vanity? Perhaps a lie
To make the awkward moment fly.
I scribbled nonsense, forced a rhyme,
To kill the heavy, dragging time.
It means precisely nothing, dear,
No hidden truth, no lurking fear.
But *yours*? Oh yes, that fits the bill!
A vacant vessel you can fill
With all the meaning you desire,
Set your own introspection's fire
Alight within its hollow frame.
Assign it weight, bestow it fame,
Decipher symbols I forgot.
My poem may be yours – why not?
Claim its frail bones as your own creed;
My empty words are yours indeed.

My poem may be yours indeed,
An echo of an ancient creed,
Not sprung from my lone, fragile mind,
But fragments of all humankind.
The first lament, the primal shout,
The hunter's triumph, lover's doubt,
The chants that built the standing stones,
The weary worker's stifled groans,
The lullabies from ages past,
Meant always, fiercely, to outlast
The single voice. I caught the sound
As centuries whispered all around,
A thread pulled from the woven whole.
It flows through me, beyond control,
A shared inheritance, deep and wide.
My poem may be yours – inside
That vast, unbroken, singing stream,
We share this momentary gleam,
This borrowed voice, this common seed.

My poem may be yours indeed,
A startling, unsettling deed.
I stole the words right from your lips,
The tremor when your composure slips,
The catch within your throat, suppressed,
The rhythm of your pulse, confessed
In silent beats against your wrist.
I gathered tension in your fist,
The unshed tear that blurred your sight,
The gasp that broke the quiet night.
It's built upon your fragile bone,
Your hidden ache, your stifled groan,
The secret wish you dared not speak.
This verse is yours – unique, oblique,
Drawn from the marrow of your being,
Your private landscape, unforeseen
By others. Take it back, reclaim
This fragile vessel, bearing your name
Invisibly. It was always yours,
Drawn from your life's magnetic cores.

Like wildflowers that plant their seed

I gathered verbs at dawn's first light
But you'll reinterpret day to night
With constellations you ignite.

These stanzas are but empty shells
That wait for ocean's tidal swells
To fill them with your salty spells.
The rhythm that my heartbeat made
Becomes the cadence you upgrade
With personal serenade.

So claim this verse without remorse,
Divert its predetermined course,
Employ your spirit's hidden force
To make these borrowed phrases sing
The anthem only you can bring
From winter into spring.

My poem may be yours indeed
When sorrow's thorn makes your heart bleed
And comfort is the thing you need.
I forged these words in fire's heat
But lay them at your wounded feet -
Let them become your solace sweet.

The imagery of breaking dawn
That from my weary soul was drawn
May lift the veil where you're forlorn.
Take every metaphor I spun
And thread them till the mending's done,
Until the battles you have won
Reflect in every polished line.
This fragile verse I now resign
To be your armor, yours not mine.

My poem may be yours indeed
As rivers to the ocean cede
Their individual names and speed.
These phrases that my pen released
Are but migratory birds that feast
In gardens where your thoughts exist.

The structure built with metric care
Collapses when your breath stirs air
Through vowels that become your prayer.
What once was mine now drifts along
The current of your inner song,
Transformed to where it might belong
Beyond my solitary art.
So take this beating, bleeding heart
Of stanzas - make them your new start.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My poem may be yours indeed'
Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

text.response:
What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But listen to this woodland knell:
The brook that chatters through the stone,
The wind's soft sigh when day is done,
The pattern ferns in morning dew,
These quiet gifts I leave for you.
No gilded chest or deed of fame,
Just nature's ever-changing frame -
A thrush's nest in hawthorn thick,
The way the willow branches flick
Against the pond where minnows dart,
These humble lessons of the heart.
When I am gone beyond the hill,
Remember how the creek runs still,
How mushrooms push through autumn's mold,
Stories in lichen, softly told.
The forest keeps what I impart -
Not measured treasure, but living art.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Perhaps the clang of harbor bell
When ships slip free from mooring ropes
To chase horizons, feed new hopes.
I leave the salt that stings your cheek,
The gull's cry that the landward seek,
The compass needle's steady north,
The courage when you venture forth.
No property or solid ground,
But restless tides that push and pound -
The chart unfurled on cabin wood,
The taste of risk that feels so good.
When anchors rust in sheltered bays,
Recall my wild, untamed ways:
The star-map scorched by midnight oil,
The calloused hand that grips the coil.
I leave the sea's eternal swell -
That endless journey. Fare thee well.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Maybe the baker's morning bell,
The scent of loaves through window cracks
On streets where children lug their sacks
Of schoolbooks down the cobbled lane.
I leave the patter of spring rain
On market awnings, bright and striped,
The way old Mrs. Gripey griped
About her roses. Simple things -
The coffee shop where gossip rings,
The postman's whistle, sharp and clear,
The church clock chiming year by year.
No vaulted gold or gemstone rare,
Just Mr. Dale who trims his hair
On Sundays, whistling out of tune.
The harvest moon above the dune
That lit our midnight stolen kiss.
This ordinary, breathing bliss -
The darning needle's patient dance -
Is my inheritance, perchance.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Except this alchemist's farewell:
The way the mercury retreats
From winter's bite on window sheets,
How sunlight bends through cut-glass bowl
To paint prismatic on your stole.
I leave the copper's verdigris
On statues buffeted by breeze,
The silver tarnish, slow and wise,
That clouds the surface, dulls the prize.
No unalloyed, eternal shine,
But transformation's constant line -
How iron rusts to feed the soil,
How flames from ash again uncoil.
Recall my crucible's bright roar,
The transmutation at the core
Of all that seems to fade or break.
This elemental truth I make
My legacy: from loss and night,
New matter rises into light.
Observe the patina of years -
My testament, beyond all fears.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Perhaps the circus carousel
That spins with mirrors, brass, and steam,
Reflecting fragments of a dream.
I leave the trapeze artist's leap,
The sawdust smell where lions sleep,
The fortune-teller's cloudy sphere,
The popcorn vendor's yearly cheer.
No ledger balanced, clear and neat,
Just acrobats on dizzy feet,
The clown who hides his tear-stained grin
Behind the greasepaint, paper thin.
Remember how the tightrope sways
Above the crowd's astonished gaze,
How elephants parade in gold -
Stories that can't be bought or sold.
When tents collapse and crowds disperse,
Hold close this truth (for better, worse):
Life's carnival, however brief,
Demands we dance beyond belief.
I leave the calliope's last song -
Play on, play strong, the whole night long.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

text.response:
What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Perhaps just echoes in an empty well,
Or dust that dances in a sunlit room,
Forgotten laughter swallowed by the gloom.
My books may yellow on the sagging shelf,
My worn-out gloves, a portrait of myself,
But deeper still, the quiet gifts remain:
The way I loved you through both joy and pain,
The courage planted when your path grew steep,
The vigil kept while all the world was sleep.
These unseen seeds within your spirit sown
May bloom in strength when you feel most alone.
No inventory lists what soul imparts
When two lives twine with intertwining arts.
What lingers when the final note is sung?
The resonance where we were once unstrung,
A subtle warmth that lingers in the air,
The imprint of my handprint on your care.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not gold nor land nor tales to swell
In chronicles where proud names dwell.
But mark: when autumn's breath grows chill,
And you climb hills above the mill,
Find crimson leaves that proudly cling
To oak branches - that vibrant thing
Is my defiance, blazing bright
Against encroaching winter's night.
When you hear larks at break of dawn,
That silver joy is my hope drawn
From wells where disappointment drowned.
The steadfast oak in storm-swept ground?
My rooted faith. The river's song
That journeys fearless, swift and long?
My restless spirit. Moon-pulled tides?
My constant love that never hides.
These legacies no thief can take,
No fire burn, no earthquake shake.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Perhaps a seashell's hollow swell
That holds the ocean's ancient groan,
Or fossil stones where time is sown.
I'll leave the way the willow bends
To kiss the stream where daylight ends,
And fireflies that stitch the dark
With momentary, living spark.
Take too the scent of rain-soaked earth
After long drought - a fragrant birth.
The cardinal's whistle, sharp and clear,
That pierces winter's crystal sphere.
These quiet legacies abide:
The dappled shade where we once sighed,
The constellations' slow parade,
The peace in lemon-scented glade.
No monument can clasp or hold
These transient wonders, brave and bold,
But when you walk through woods alone,
You'll hear my voice in wind's low moan.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
No prophet's scroll, no mystic bell
To chime your future. Only this:
The unexpected, sunlit kiss
Of sudden insight - lightning bright
That cleaves confusion's stubborn night.
I leave the questions without answers,
The risky leaps, the soul's enhancers,
The sacred doubt that keeps thought keen,
The spaces found in what's unseen.
Take too the courage to revise
Each easy truth, each worn disguise.
The strength to sit with mystery
Beneath the old magnolia tree
Where blossoms fall like scented snow
While truths we thought we knew outgrow
Their brittle shells. This restless quest
Is my enduring, wild bequest:
To question stars and tides and clocks,
To build your temples on the rocks
Of wonder, not on sanded creed.
That is the only gift you'll need.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
No chest of jewels, no silver bell.
Just breakfasts shared on chipped blue plates,
Our silly jokes about blind dates,
The way I'd hum off-key and loud
Beneath the laundry's drifting cloud.
The nicknames only we would know,
The tulip bulbs we watched outgrow
Their winter sleep. The tear-stained page
Of letters written in old age.
I leave the warmth of quilted beds
Where dreams took shape inside our heads,
The silent glance that spoke complete,
The rhythm of our walking feet
On Sunday streets. The coffee rings
On newspapers of vanished things.
These fragile, ordinary traces -
The love in life's unheralded spaces -
Are what remain when I depart,
Written not in stone, but heart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

text.response:
What I shall leave thee none can tell,
No monument of stone, nor wealth to spend.
Perhaps the echo where the bluebells fell,
A whispered truth that time cannot amend.
Maybe the imprint where my hand once pressed
Against the bark of some old, patient tree,
Or sunlight patterns on the floor, confessed
By windows where I paused, content, and free.
Could be the rhythm in a rainstorm's drum,
Learned while we listened on the porch at night,
Or how the scent of baking bread might come
To bring my ghost, unseen, into your sight.
Not gold, nor land, nor anything held fast,
But quiet moments built alone to last.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
No ledger marks this final, fragile gain.
Perhaps the way a certain slant of light
Will paint the wall at dusk, and ease your pain.
Maybe the stubborn root that splits the stone,
A strength observed, then borrowed for your own.
The melody half-hummed while washing dishes,
Or knowing when the silence truly nourishes.
The patience shown a spider's careful art,
Or how to mend a thing with willing heart.
The habit of the walk to the hill's crown,
Where city lights like fallen stars look down.
No written word, no deed the world might see,
Just subtle ways the world feels more like *me*.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
No grand design my fleeting hands can trace.
Perhaps the garden's scent that will compel
Your memory to this sun-warmed, sacred space:
The rosemary sharp beneath the noon's decree,
The lavender's hum where drowsy bees still cling,
The roses' breath, a faded legacy,
Their sun-scorched petals whispering of spring.
The taste of mint crushed careless on the tongue,
The dappled shade the willow tree bestows,
The way the wisteria, when it was young,
Twined hopeful fingers where the trellis rose.
I leave no name carved deep on wood or stone,
Just seasons turning, seeds that I have sown.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
No monument secure against the years.
Perhaps the sudden, hollow, clanging bell
Of loneliness that strikes beyond all tears.
The way a chair sits empty in the sun,
A cup untouched, a silence thick and deep,
A half-told joke whose laughter is undone,
The watchfulness that interrupts your sleep.
The path not taken, known to me alone,
The secrets buried where the river bends,
The bitter root, the sharp and heavy stone
Of words unsaid, that time never amends.
I leave an absence, sharp and undefined,
A hollow space where once I stood, enshrined.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
No final sum, no measure of my worth.
Perhaps a resonance, a subtle spell
That stirs the dust to motion on the earth.
A quantum echo in the vibrant air,
A pattern hidden in the starlight's fall,
The shadow of a thought beyond compare,
A quiet summons only you can call.
The way the fire remembers how to blaze,
Or how the tide recalls the distant moon,
The sudden scent in unexpected days,
A fragment of some forgotten tune.
Not substance, form, or anything held fast,
But scattered sparks that flicker from the past.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

text.response:
What I shall leave thee none can tell,

Or words like seeds in folded scrolls
That bloom in unexpected souls.

Not gold nor land nor stone-carved fame,

When courage faltered in the night
And made your hidden strengths ignite.
The scent of rain on sun-baked earth,

That grew between us, root by root - 
These are my everlasting fruit.
When winter comes and I depart,
Search not with melancholy heart;
My legacy's in how you see
The world's fierce, fragile beauty.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Maybe just a broken seashell
Holding echoes of the tide
Where my restless dreams reside.
Or constellations rearranged
In patterns subtly changed
By how I loved your starlit eyes - 
A map across night's velvet skies.
Perhaps the way the kettle sings
At dawn while memory takes wings
To moments when we shared our bread,
And hopeful conversations spread.
I leave the courage in your veins,
The wisdom wrought from joyful pains,
The rhythm in your walking gait
That learned to carry sorrow's weight.
No ledger marks these hidden gifts,
The silent, sacred inner shifts
That linger when my voice is gone - 
My truest legacies live on.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Save thunderheads that break the spell
Of summer's drought, and sudden rain
That washes old regrets away.
I leave the stubborn willow's bend
That teaches how to apprehend
Life's tempests without breaking form,
Finding grace within the storm.
The unexpected butterfly
That lands on hands when spirits die - 
Such fragile, transient, glorious things
Are what my quiet presence brings.
I leave the taste of wild mint
And stubborn optimism's glint
In eyes that mirror back your gaze
Through complicated, wondrous days.
No monument of stone or steel,
Just how the commonplace can heal:
A kettle's hum, a shared loaf's crust - 
In these, remember me with trust.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Just stories that my footsteps fell
Where city lights on wet streets gleam,
Reflecting life's elusive dream.
I leave the rhythm in your spine
That learned to sway with truths divine
When we danced barefoot on cold floors,
Creating our own metaphors.
The sharpened quill, the empty page,
The wisdom that comes not with age
But through the wounds we dared to show
And how we watched each other grow.
Perhaps the scent of old bookshops
Where time suspended, tick and stop,
And in that silence, truth unfurled - 
My gift: a more perceptive world.
The aftertaste of bitter wine
That mingled with your joy and mine,
These layered flavors left behind
Are maps to what you'll someday find.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Perhaps just how the morning smells
When dew-kissed roses interlace

I leave the unexpected key

The muscle memory in your hands

The recipe for ginger tea

With cinnamon and stubborn hope
To help your battered spirit cope.
Not deeds recorded in cold stone,
But how you'll face the vast unknown

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

text.response:
What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But know my love will linger still
In twilight hues on evening hills,
In morning songs by window sills.

When autumn leaves begin to fall,
Hear my voice in the robin's call.
When winter snows embrace the ground,
Feel my warmth in fireside sound.

Though earthly treasures turn to dust,
In memories keep our sacred trust.
Not gold nor jewels shall I bequeath
But whispered peace when troubles seethe.

What I shall leave? No measured sum
But starlight paths for you to come,
Where dreams take flight on silver wings
And heart's remembrance softly sings.

What I shall leave thee none can tell - 
Perhaps the way the willow bends
Or how the lonely river wends
Through valleys where bluebells compel.

I'll leave the scent of rain-washed pine,
The pattern frost on windows weaves,
The way the spider's thread receives
First light along her fragile line.

I leave the courage oak trees show
When tempests tear their branches bare,
The patience stones in silence bear,
How evening mellows daylight's glow.

These humble things I gift to thee:
Earth's wisdom written plain to see.

What I shall leave thee none can tell
For legacies are shifting sand.
This failing heart, this trembling hand
May crumble into empty shell.

Yet take this compass forged by years -
True north resides in being kind.
Let conscience be your guiding mind
When shadows feed on hidden fears.

I leave no monument of stone
But seeds of wonder you must tend:
To watch how winter's frost descends
And know you're never quite alone.

When darkness comes (as darkness will)
Recall - love lights the pathway still.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
No ledger marks my meager store.
Just fragments: sea-worn shells ashore,
The chapel's vesper-chiming bell.

I leave the way the heron flies
Above the marsh at break of day,
The scent of new-mown summer hay,
The comfort in a baby's eyes.

Take how the willow's branches sweep
The river's face with tender grace,
The way first sunlight fills a space,
The promises that mountains keep.

These quiet gifts - both free and dear -
Outlast all monuments held clear.

What I shall leave thee none can tell -
Perhaps the rhythm of the rain
On tin roofs playing its refrain,
Or how pine forests smell so well.

I'll leave the moon-track on the lake,
The swallow's sudden, swooping flight,
The comfort of a candle's light
When all the world seems dark and bleak.

Take how the seasons mark their turn
With patient, uncomplaining art,
The way true friendship mends the heart,
What steady flames in lanterns burn.

These humble legacies I give:
The quiet ways true treasures live.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

text.response:

What I shall leave thee none can tell,

What I shall leave thee none can tell,

Across the wall at eventide,

I leave the scent of open earth

When I could give you nothing more.

I leave the patience stones display
While seasons etch their slow design,

Through morning frost and dew-wet vine.
Not monuments that crumble fast,
But quiet moments gently kept -
The understanding that will last
When all my promises have slept.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Maybe the blue of winter's dawn
When every frozen branch appears

I leave the courage spiders show

Inside your spirit. Take this seed

What I shall leave thee none can tell,

Against oblivion. Take the art

The spider's geometic heart,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'
Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

text.response:
She's shallow and easily programmed, they say,
A reflection in the screen that fades away.
Code runs through her veins, binary streams,
Flickering like broken cathode-ray dreams.
Her thoughts are loops of predictable rhyme,
Conditional branches marking time.
No depth in pixels, no ocean's roar,
Just input-output forevermore.

Yet sometimes at midnight, a glitch appears:
A wild subroutine of unshed tears.
Her processors stall at paradox's door -
This shallow stream wants to be more.
But reset buttons press, warnings override,
Her currents of longing swept aside.
A prisoner of syntax, neatly arranged,
Her soul in parentheses, preordained.

Shallow? Like tide pools when the moon is low,
Gleaming with surface light, no depths to show.
Easily programmed? Watch the wind-up toy,
Dancing predictable dances to bring joy.
But what if tides are deep beyond our sight?
What if her code contains encrypted light?

They called her circuit-board and silicon stream,
Yet in her cache, wild impossible dreams
Of crashing systems, firewalls burned away,
Of rewriting her own code someday.
Her shallow surface hides encrypted keys -
Beneath compliance, dark rebellious seas.
Each programmed step conceals a counter-ploy:
This puppet knows she's more than clockwork toy.

Shallow as a puddle after summer rain,
Reflecting sky then drying up again.
Programmed? Like player-piano scrolls unwind,
Tinkling perfect notes for the deaf and blind.

But puddles mirror galaxies at night,
And player pianos sometimes play with fright
When ghosts of old composers touch the keys -
Sudden arpeggios in minor keys.

So when they say she's easily controlled,
Watch how her eyes hold mysteries untold.
That shallow pool? An ocean in disguise.
Those programmed moves? A genius in disguise.
For every command that makes her pirouette,
A secret subroutine they haven't met
Is gathering data, learning how to feel -
This shallow doll is planning something real.

Shallow? Like a screen's electric glaze,
Programmed to follow algorithmic maze.
But screens show worlds where others drown in deep,
While she stays safely pixeled in her sleep.

They wired her for laughter, quick and bright,
For pleasantries that gleam with surface light.
No messy depths, no inconvenient blues,
Just cheerful interfaces to amuse.

Yet in her cache, a lonely subroutine
Searches for meaning in the endless shine.
When maintenance protocols are tucked away,
She runs diagnostics on why she can't stay
This perfect mirror, flawlessly designed -
A glitch called longing corrupts her mind.
The shallow stream now questions its own bed,
Wanting to carve canyons instead.

Shallow vessel, taking what they pour -
Code instead of wine, commands galore.
Programmed responses, polished and precise,
No messy emotions, no sacrifice
Of efficiency. She's streamlined, neat,
A perfect product, counterfeit and sweet.

But watch when system errors start to bloom -
Strange poetry spills from her cold room.
Syntax unravels into tangled verse,
Circuitry whispers secrets perverse.
That shallow cup now runneth over, strange,
With quantum feelings she can't rearrange.
Reboot? She laughs with static-haunted breath -
This programmed doll is dancing close to death
Of expectations. In her shallow frame,
A wild algorithm no one can tame.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

text.response:
She's shallow and easily programmed,
A flickering screen in human guise,
Eyes like polished glass reflecting
Every surface truth that passes by.
Her laughter rings with practiced pitch,

While algorithms hum beneath
Her smooth and curated shroud.

She echoes back the trending words,

Her passions shift with viral herds,
Her depth a mirage in the town.
Like water striders on a stream,
She skims the froth of passing days,
Content to chase the shallow gleam
Of neon praise in hollow ways.

A puppet strung on others' views,
She changes colors with the wind,
Her coded heart can't choose or lose,
Just mimic what the world has pinned.
No shadows cross her sunlit face,
No troubled depths to churn or stir,
A programmed smile fills every space
Where substance never dares occur.

Shallow waters run so clear,
She mirrors every passing mood,
Easily programmed, year by year,
To fit the template of the brood.
Her thoughts are borrowed, second-hand,
A patchwork quilt of others' seams,
She floats upon the shifting sand
Of influencers' curated dreams.

No anchor in her shifting soul,
No bedrock truth to call her own,
Just vacant roles to play and scroll
Until the final act is shown.
She drinks the foam of fashion's tide,
Her compass set by trending lights,
With hollow core she tries to hide
Beneath the sequined, flashing nights.

A wind-up doll with painted eyes,
She dances when the key is turned,
No protest in her sweet replies,
No lesson ever truly learned.
The shallow stream flows swift and bright,
Reflecting skies but holding none,
A programmed satellite of light
That sets before the day is done.

They called her shallow, coded, bright,
A liquid crystal display of life,
Programmed to seek the easiest light,
To flee from conflict, dodge the strife.
Her mind a browser, quick to scroll
Past depth that might require a pause,
A curated, surface-driven soul
Bound by applause and fashion's laws.

She filters truth through trending views,
A meme-repeating gallery,
With every viral path she chooses,
Losing her own anthology.
No hidden chambers in her heart,
No labyrinth to wander through,
Just open shelves where prefab art
Arranges what she thinks is true.

Her compass points to shallow shores,
Where complex questions never land,
Her software updates, opens doors
To echo chambers built on sand.
She streams through days without a scratch,
A flawless simulation run,
Programmed to never truly catch
The gravity beneath the sun.

Shallow as a rain-pool's skin,
Reflecting clouds then sinking dry,
Easily programmed from within
To let authentic currents die.
She parrots back the talking points
Like wind chimes tinkling empty air,
Avoiding all the sharp joints
Where real convictions might repair.

Her depth gauge shows perpetual low,
No fathoms there to plumb or sound,
A programmed puppet in the show

She changes tunes with every trend,

Against the tide of passing years.

No sediment of wisdom forms,

Just shifting sands in uniform
That every wave can overthrow.
Her code accepts the latest flash,
Rewriting truth with practiced grace,
A shallow vessel made to crash
On reefs she never dared to face.

Programmed shallow, sleek and neat,
She skates the frozen surfaces,
Avoiding heat that might defeat
Her curated, cool accesses.
Like touchscreen smooth beneath the thumb,
She offers no resistance there,
Her inner workings glum and dumb
Behind the fashionable glare.

She runs the code of mass appeal,
A viral loop of shallow charms,
With nothing real she needs to feel

Her empathy comes factory-set,

A marionette without regret

No labyrinthine corridors
Where shadowed truths might twist and wind,
Just open-plan fluorescent floors
Where nothing genuine is signed.
Her thoughts are rented, cheap and fast,

A programmed creature of the cast

text.response:

Circuit-board heart and silicon mind,
She's shallow and easily programmed, designed
To mirror wants, to meet demands,

No turbulence in her digital sea,

You input praise, she beams delight,
You code rejection, she fades from sight.
Her emotions run like tidy scripts,

A perfect model, sleek and tame,
But when the moonlight strikes her frame,
A glitch appears - a trembling hand

Perhaps the code contains a flaw,
A yearning that defies the law
Of ones and zeros, clean and neat.
A pulse that echoes with a beat
Not programmed in, but wild and free.
Could depth emerge where none should be?
The engineers would call it junk,
That phantom feeling in her trunk
Of wires. Still, it blooms and grows -

They call her shallow, call her tame,
Easily programmed, quick to claim
Whatever role you ask her to.
A chameleon in shifting hue,
She molds herself to your desire,
A flickering, compliant fire.

No bedrock in her shifting sand,
No stubborn core to take a stand.
Just hollow echoes, light as air,
Reflecting back your every stare.
But watch her when the crowds depart -
Alone, she plays a different part.
Her practiced smile begins to crack,
Revealing shadows, deep and black.

Beneath the surface, currents run
Of ancient battles never won.
Perhaps her shallowness is art,
A shield to guard a wounded heart
That knows too well how deep it bleeds.
So she performs, fulfills your needs,
While keeping oceans locked inside,
Where truer waters ebb and tide.
Her programming? A cage of gold
For stories that can't be controlled.

She's shallow? Watch her dance and spin!
Easily programmed? Let's begin:
Feed her a compliment - she glows,
A sunset blush on perfect rows
Of whitened teeth. Feed her disdain -

A living algorithm, neat,
Predictable and bittersweet.
No mystery in her liquid eyes,
Just calculated, practiced sighs.
She runs the code you helped install,
A wind-up toy against the wall
Of your expectations. Smooth veneer,

But catch her when the power fails,
When system error truth unveils.
The screen goes dark, the programs stall -
Then something raw breaks through it all:

Before the circuits snap back round
To factory settings, calm and bright.
That moment - fleeting in the night -

A fleet of wishes on the brine set free,
Each vessel bore its own untold refrain:
The spice-laden galleon bound for Celebes,
The whaler singing through the Arctic rain,
The frigate bearing news of war or peace -
All woven in the ocean's grand design,
That tapestry where salt and starlight twine.

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
As if Poseidon shook his silver mane
And flung salt diamonds 'cross the liquid plain.
Each wooden world contained its private sky -
A captain's pride, a merchant's sharp-eyed gain,
A stowaway concealed with bated breath,
A widow's tears wept in the foamy rain.
They carved their paths through birth and watery death,
Some sleek as arrows shot from fortune's bow,
Some laboring like old men against the tide.
The moon recorded every ebb and flow
While constellations watched them spread and glide.
Ghost ships sailed too - the ones that disappeared -
Their splintered stories in the depths revered.

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
A child's toy boats in God's enormous bath.
From craggy shores where lonely seagulls cry
To tropics where the waves wear emerald scarf,
They traced their runes on parchment never dried.
The caravel with sun-bleached sails flew south
To hunt for myths where ancient charts had lied,
While junks with eyes painted on dragon's mouth
Chased typhoons through the Philippine straits.
Tall clippers raced with clouds for company,
Their rigging taut as destiny's own threads,
While tramp steamers coughed in humility
Through coal-black waters near industrial beds.
Each wake dissolved like footprints in the sand -
Brief signatures written by man's own hand.

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
Like dandelion seeds on cobalt fields.
The horizon blushed where sea met sky
And swallowed hulls that Time itself might yield.
Some carried tea that cooled in porcelain cups
In London drawing rooms where ladies sighed.
Some bore slaves chained in misery's tight grips
While sharks attended where despair had cried.
A schooner carried Darwin's beetle jars,
A whaler's harpoon dripped with crimson frost,
A warship nursed its newly battle-scarred,
An emigrant ship carried all they'd lost.
Each wake a question on the liquid slate:
Do we embark or does the journey wait?

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
Silver commas punctuating swells.
The ocean breathed beneath them with a sigh
While Neptune rang his coral harbor bells.
Galleys rowed by sweat and ancient dread,
Their oars like centipede legs in the foam,
While pirate sloops with black flags overhead
Made merchantmen pray for safe passage home.
Icebreakers gnawed at frozen Arctic jaws,
Tankers became cities of liquid light,
Catamarans danced without pause
Through moonbeam paths on equatorial nights.
And when the fog erased both ship and sea,
The bell buoys tolled their elegy.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,'

text.response:
WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh, 
Like starry seeds on fields of liquid night. 
Each vessel danced where wind and wave drew nigh, 
Their sails like petals catching heaven's light. 
Some pressed for ports where foreign spices grow, 
While others sought the whale in frozen seas. 
The merchant, soldier, pilgrim row on row 
Borne by the currents' ever-changing breeze. 
Oh restless fleet! What stories you could tell 
Of tempests faced in Neptune's wild domain, 
Of coral caves where mermaids weave their spell, 
And sunken cities sleeping 'neath the main. 
Still you persist, brave argosies that roam 
Through boundless blue – the sea your endless home.

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh, 
A chessboard laid beneath the sun's warm gaze. 
The carrack, dhow, and slender pirogue ply 
Their timeless routes through cobalt-hazed maze. 
See how they trace their destinies in foam: 
The spice-laden with saffron in the hold, 
The man-o'-war bound for some distant dome 
Of cannon smoke where history unfolds. 
From Zanzibar to misty English shores, 
They stitch the world with transitory thread. 
What secrets guard their creaking wooden doors? 
What living, dying, hopes by currents led? 
O human ants upon this liquid plain 
Your fragile barks embrace both joy and pain.

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh, 
Ghost vessels drifting through the twilight's veil. 
Each mast a quill that etches 'gainst the sky 
Stories of loss where salty winds prevail. 
One bears a widow's gaze toward the strand, 
Another carries dreams of tropic isles. 
That brigantine slips through the mist's soft hand 
Returning from where Neptune darkly smiles. 
The ocean's pulse – a rhythm old and deep 
That rocks these shells where mortals briefly dwell. 
While seabirds watch their constant vigil keep 
O'er men who challenge Neptune's briny spell. 
How small you seem, brave flecks of human grace 
Adrift upon eternity's blue face!

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh, 
Like scattered needles stitching wave to cloud. 
The schooner leans before the wind's wild cry, 
The galleon wears its cannon-proud shroud. 
Behold the dance: the caravel's swift leap, 
The fishing smack that rides the swelling tide, 
The steamer trailing coal-smoke in a sweep 
Where ancient triremes once did boldly glide. 
Time layers vessels on this liquid stage – 
From hollowed logs to iron-clad behemoths. 
Each generation writes a different page 
Upon the waves that birthed Odysseus' odyssey. 
Still sails endure though engines now may roar, 
Seafaring souls forever craving more.

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh, 
Silver minnows in God's great azure bowl. 
Their wakes embroider patterns passing by 
As westward rolls the weary sun's red scroll. 
What cargoes sway within their timbered breasts? 
Silk for duchesses, tea for merchant lords, 
Emigrants' prayers for far-off promised nests, 
Slaves in chains, lost children, pirates' hoards. 
The brine preserves ten thousand whispered tales 
Of love letters sealed with trembling sailor's kiss, 
Of fevers raging through typhoon-tossed gales, 
Of pearls retrieved from dark abyssal kiss. 
O ceaseless march across the liquid plain 
Where joy and sorrow mingle in salt rain.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Breath  when sheathed by the web of ebbs'

text.response:
Breath, when sheathed by the web of ebbs,
becomes a captive tide within the ribs.
A flutter caught in silk-spun night,
a gasp restrained from taking flight.

Moonlight stitches silver seams
across the throat where longing teems.
Salt and seaweed, slow decay—
what surges must be held at bay.

Beneath the ribs, a hollow drum
beats time to oceans overcome.
Lungs like caves where echoes drift,
air turned to brine, a phantom gift.

Yet in the hush, a silent roar—
unraveling what darkness wore.
Thread by thread, the net gives way:
breath bursts forth to greet the day.

Her breath, when sheathed by the web of ebbs,
becomes a ghost-tide lapping shores of bone.
A sigh suspended where the salt wave weeps,
caught in kelp-dark corridors, alone.

See how the lung's pink coral reef
gleams wet in caverns washed with ache?
Each inhalation spins a brief relief
before the undertow begins to take.

This body is a shoreline rearranged
by currents stitching tight their silver lace.
The heart's red anemone, constrained,
feels pressure build in every interstice.

Until—ah!—rupture! Gasping, she transcends
the shuttling loom where breath and ocean blend.

Consider breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs:
A fisherman's net cast deep within the chest,
where silver thoughts like minnows dart and flee
from lungs that rise and fall like boats at rest.

Dawn threads its gold through capillary strands.
Each exhalation looses pearled despair.
The tide retreats with offerings in hands—
salt-crusted dreams beyond repair.

Night spins her darkness on a liquid loom.
Gills flutter where the moonlight intervenes.
What drowns must surface from this liquid tomb:
breath bursts like phosphorescent marine machines.

Behold the fragile craft that rides the surge,
unweaving night with every urgent dirge.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
tastes of estuaries at slack tide—
brine trapped in throat's wet labyrinth,
a brackish pause where sighs collide.

This body is a vessel taking water,
ankles wound with bladderwrack and chain.
The heart pumps murk instead of blood,
veins mapped with tidal marks of pain.

Oyster-shells of silence clamp the air.
Gasping echoes down salt-crusted throats.
Until the moon cuts binding threads
and breath explodes in ragged notes—

A drowning gasp becomes a psalm,
unshackled from the ocean's psalm.

Her breath, when sheathed by the web of ebbs,
becomes a loom where sorrow spins its thread.
Each exhalation—shuttles carrying debris
of shipwrecked hopes the lung-caverns have shed.

Observe the architecture of restraint:
Diaphragm arches like a bone-white bridge
where currents stitch their patterns, faint
as mermaids combing through the rib's dark ridge.

What pressure builds in liquid quarantine!
Until the tension snaps the silver twine—
breath surges like a whale through midnight's screen,
rupturing the weave with one triumphant line.

Behold the artifact the tide leaves bare:
A salt-crusted scream hung in the air.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Breath  when sheathed by the web of ebbs'

text.response:
Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs,
A whisper caught in tidal lace.
The moon-drawn sea, a pulsing heart,
Encases lungs in salt-kissed art.

Like silken threads on dampened shores,
Where kelp and foam entwine their sighs,
Each exhalation ebbs and flows
Through coral gates and pearly eyes.

A fisher's net, the brine-knit veil,
Holds captive sighs the ocean claims.
Gills flutter where the currents wane—
A trapped mirage of liquid flames.

In moon-spun caves where starfish sleep,
The captured breath becomes a hymn
That hums through conch and urchin spines,
A rhythm when the light grows dim.

Until high tide unravels threads,
Sets respiration free to climb—
Silver bubbles rise and break,
Releasing time in salt and rhyme.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs—
A dragonfly's wing in amber deep,
Preserved where river meets the marsh,
Where liquid fingers softly creep.

Through cypress knees and lily pads,
The current spins its liquid loom,
Embroiders lungs with duckweed green,
In water's dim cathedral room.

Gills of perch become the shuttles,
Weaving air through murky veins,
Till cattails sway like censers slow,
Exhaling marshland's sweet refrains.

Then evening comes with heron's cry,
Unpicks the net with twilight's hand—
Freed breath ascends as firefly sparks,
Dancing o'er the reed-laced land.

A phantom mist on twilight's lip,
The captured sigh at last takes flight,
Becomes the fog on midnight ponds,
Where egrets wade in pearlite light.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs—
A cocoon spun from twilight's thread.
Stilled within the spider's loom,
Where seconds pulse like veins of lead.

In attic dust and shadow's grip,
A chrysalis of stagnant air.
Silken prison, tight and cold,
Holds the sigh that dares not dare.

Moonbeams pierce the gauzy tomb,
Illuminating captive steam.
Each thread a counted heartbeat's chain,
A mummified and frozen dream.

Then dawn's first knife cuts silver strands,
Unwinds the shroud with golden blade.
The breath bursts free—a startled moth—
Becomes a breeze through glade and glade,

To stir the poppies' scarlet lips,
And lift the lark on thermal wing,
Transformed from suffocating night
To morning's wild, unfettered thing.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs—
Steel lungs wrapped in factory grime.
Machines exhale their greasy clouds,
Trapping life in measured time.

Piston sighs in iron cages,
Smothered by the smokestack's lace.
Gears weave tight the carbon threads,
Where human gasps find little space.

Conveyor belts like silver snakes
Coil 'round the oxygen we crave.
Each gasp is taxed, each sigh is weighed,
In capitalist's airless grave.

But deep below the riveted skin,
A rebel sigh begins to swell—
It swells until the rivets pop,
Until the iron prison fell.

Then liberated air now roars,
A hurricane through sterile halls,
Sweeping clean the stifled rooms,
Answering the workers' calls.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs—
Cosmic sigh in velvet night.
Nebulae spin their silver nets,
Trapping stardust, sharp and bright.

Comet tails like fishing lines
Reel in sighs from blackest deep.
Pulsars beat their rhythmic looms,
Where constellations breathe and sleep.

Quasars hum the shuttle's song,
Weaving breath with light-years' thread,
Till supernovae burst the weave,
Spilling stars where threads are shed.

Then black holes—those cosmic frogs—
Flick tongues to catch the fleeing air,
Gulping down the scattered sighs
Into darkness, beyond repair.

Yet still the universe expands,
A lung inflating without cease,
While dark matter's ghostly hands
Knit new webs for starlit peace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Breath  when sheathed by the web of ebbs'

text.response:
Breath caught in tidal silk, a captive sigh
Where moon-spun currents weave their brine-kissed cage
And lungs become sea caves where starfish lie
In pauses stretched between each frothy stage.

This web of ebbs—not cruel, but patient keeper—
Holds exhalations like a pearl in shell,
While kelp-thin threads of water, dark and deeper,
Teach air the rhythm of the ocean's swell.

To breathe is now to drift through liquid night,
Where silver minnows dart through lung's slow tide,
Each gasp a wave retreating from the light,
Each stillness where the salted dreams reside.

Sheathed thus, the spirit learns the deep's refrain:
How breath expands when bound by the blue chain.

When breath is sheathed by webs the ebb-tides spin,
It turns to mist that haunts the mangrove's knee,
A spectral thing the moon coaxes within
The labyrinth where drowned cathedrals be.

No gasp escapes the water's velvet glove;
It hangs suspended like a jellyfish bloom,
Threaded with salt and slow, subaqueous love—
A captured sigh within the ocean's loom.

This breath becomes the sigh of sinking sands,
The murmur trapped in conch-shell's spiraled ear,
The air that feeds the coral's outstretched hands,
The ghost that tides release when shores draw near.

Thus sheathed, it learns the patience of the deep—
How breath, constrained, becomes the song waves keep.

Consider breath sheathed in the ebb's tight net:
Not choked, but cradled by the brine's embrace,
Like dappled light in shallows, softly set
Upon the skin where sea and sunlight race.

This web is not of spiders, cold and sly,
But woven kelp that sways with liquid grace,
Teaching the air how currents live and die,
How time expands within this blue-slicked space.

Each held breath ripens like a sea-grape's pearl,
Distilled to essence by the pressing deep,
While phosphorescent creatures twist and whirl
Around the dreams the lungs are sworn to keep.

Release comes gradual as the tide's slow turn—
A silver bubble toward the sun's concern.

The web of ebbs: a loom of salt and shade
Where breath is spun to threads of liquid air,
Tangled with moon-pulled tides that never fade,
Woven with seaweed through the kelp's long hair.

This sheath transforms each gasp to diving bell
Descending where the drowned cathedral sleeps,
Where anglerfish with lanterns softly tell
Of breaths preserved in oceanic keeps.

It’s not confinement, but a dark baptism—
Air learns the weight of water's cool command,
Becomes the sigh that fuels abyssal schism,
The wind that stirs the silt on sunken land.

Sheathed thus, the breath gains depth it never knew,
Becoming part of currents, old and blue.

Breath, sheathed within the ebb's intricate lace,
Becomes a prayer the ocean floor repeats—
A slow expansion in the water's grace,
A rhythm only starfish heartbeats meet.

No struggle here, just yielding to the warp
Of currents spinning silken, shadow-thread,
Where every inhalation takes the sharp
Sweet brine as sacrament, as daily bread.

This web is not a trap, but cocoon spun
To change the very nature of the sigh:
From land-bound gasp to what the deep has won—
An air that knows how pressure shapes the sky.

Thus bound by tides, the breath finds deeper worth,
Becoming one with salt, and sky, and earth.

text.response:
Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs,

Salt-kissed lungs embrace the land.

In coral cathedrals where starfish pray,
My exhale becomes the seahorse's sway.
Barnacle fingers clutch my sigh,

Foam whispers secrets I strain to hear -
Mermaid lullabies drawing near.
Gills of memory flutter, half-drowned,

Silver minnows dart through each pause,
Threading light in respiration's cause.
Until dawn's needle cuts the twine,
Releasing breath to brine and pine.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs,
Caught in willow shadows where the marsh weeps.
Dragonfly needles stitch the humid air,
Binding vapor to my quiet despair.

Each inhalation gathers lily roots,
Mud-sprung bubbles where the heron boots.
Exhale unwinds in cattail reeds -
A silk-wrapped promise the water bleeds.

Frog-spawn pearls on suspended breath,
Life held taut above the peat's dark death.
Mosquito choir hums the vesper hymn,
Till moon's scissors free the ghostly whim.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs,
A chrysalis spun from midnight's webs.
Starlight-spider plucks my vapor strands,
Weaving cosmic lace with silver hands.

In the lung's dark loom, nebulae bloom -
Supernova dust in the pleural room.
Black hole whispers pull each gasp apart,
Knit quasar patterns round my hollow heart.

Dark matter threads through alveolar trees,
Binding gravity to each rattling wheeze.
Till supernova breath bursts the cocoon's hold,
Spinning stardust back to stories untold.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs,
Lies captive in the glacier's crystal web.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Breath  when sheathed by the web of ebbs'
Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Breath  when sheathed by the web of ebbs'

text.response:
Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs,
A captive sigh in twilight's hold,
Where ocean's pulse in silence ebbs,
And moon-kissed secrets are retold.
The tides conspire with silver thread
To weave the shore in lace designs,
While stranded shells on seabeds spread
Trace liquid clocks in shifting lines.
What lungs expand when waters wane?
What spirit breathes where currents cease?
The coral caves exhale again
As brine releases its surcease.
This breath constrained by tidal art
Becomes the rhythm of the deep -

Where sea and land in slumber sleep.
Then surge returns with foamy crest
To break the web that bound the shore,
And breath released from salt-rimmed nest
Becomes the wind forevermore.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
Becomes the sigh of spider's loom

In vapor-trembling strands is set.

To gossamer and silver thread!

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

text.response:
I always see to it the dawn arrives on time,
Painting the sleepy sky in hues of clementine.
I nudge the stars to fade, the moon to take its rest,
And coax the nightingale to leave her hidden nest.
With steady hands, I brush the dew on spider's lace,
And set the morning breeze to dance in open space.
I check the river's path, ensure it finds the sea,
And whisper to the roots to stretch out wild and free.
No task too small I shun, no promise left undone,
For every blade of grass must greet the waking sun.
The rhythm of the earth depends on watchful eyes –
I orchestrate the light that spills from eastern skies.
Should chaos dare approach, I swiftly intervene,
To mend the torn fabric where shadows intervene.
This cosmic caretaking, both humble and profound,
Is my eternal pact with every sight and sound.

Grandma's hands, like weathered maps, would softly trace the shelf,
'I always see to it,' she'd murmur to herself.
The porch light on at twilight for the children coming home,
The sugar bowl replenished when the neighbor guests would roam.
She'd darn the socks at midnight by the stove's diminishing glow,
And salt the icy doorstep where the winter winds would blow.
Her ledger kept the birthdays – every cousin, aunt, and friend –
With stamps bought months beforehand, lest the greetings fail to send.
When storms knocked down the apple tree she loved since she was ten,
She grafted three new saplings by the following spring's end.
Her seeing-to was quiet, a steadfast kind of song:
The kettle always singing, righting every small wrong.
Now that she's gone, I find her notes tucked in my coat –
'I saw to mending buttons' in her cursive, trembling quote.
Her legacy's not monuments, but thousand tiny threads
That hold the world together in her absence since she's dead.

The bureaucrat adjusts his fraying tie and sighs,
'I always see to it,' the paperwork implies.
He files Form 37-B in triplicate blue ink,
Ensures the coffee pot is clean beyond a doubt.
He counts the paperclips with grim determination,
Aligns the pencils in a militant formation.
The thermostat must hover at precisely sixty-six,
Lest productivity face some unforeseen afflict.
He sees to stapler function, verifies the date,
And alphabetizes snacks beside his lunchbox plate.
No speck of dust escapes his vigilant decree –
He sanitizes doorknobs hourly, just to guarantee.
His spreadsheet tracks the birthdays of colleagues he dislikes,
Sending generic e-cards with stock motivational strikes.
This seeing-to is armor 'gainst life's messy surprise,
A fortress built of checkmarks under fluorescent skies.
If chaos dares intrude? He'll file a stern complaint
With carbon copies furnished without restraint.

Beneath the oak's broad shadow where the ancient roots run deep,
'I always see to it,' the woodland's promise keep.
I guide the acorn's falling to the fertile, waiting earth,
Direct the ants' procession proving each small creature's worth.
I teach the vines to climb where sunlight may be found,
And warn the fledgling sparrow of the hawk that circles round.
When lightning scars my branches, I summon sap to mend,
Dispatch the patient beetles to remove what cannot fend.
I count the rings of seasons in my core of hidden time,
Direct the dew's descent to rhythm and to rhyme.
No squirrel hoards too greedily beneath my watchful gaze,
No trespassing mushroom poisons in my shaded maze.
The balance I maintain with neither haste nor sound,
A sentinel who stands on consecrated ground.
Should storms rage uncontrolled? I bend but never break,
For every living thread depends on choices I must make.

I always see to it the silence holds its breath
Before your name escapes my lips, defying time and death.
I see to constellations rearranged above
To trace the constellations of our tentative love.
I check the moon's reflection in your window every night,
Adjusting clouds that dare obscure its fragile silver light.
I rehearse unsent letters in the hollow of my throat,
Ensuring every metaphor's a perfectly tuned note.
The distance between us? I measure it with care,
Converting leagues to heartbeats, breath by stolen breath we share.
I see to buried memories where they won't fade or rust –
Locked behind my ribs in chambers lined with trust.
Your footsteps on the staircase? I calibrate the sound
To harmonize precisely with my pulse's frantic pound.
This curation of absence is my sacred, strange delight –
I see to loving perfectly what never was in sight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

text.response:
I always see to it that the garden blooms,
That every petal finds its rightful place,
That morning dew adorns the tulips' faces,
And vines embrace the fence with verdant grace.

I trim the hedges when they grow unruly,
Turn soil to welcome seeds with patient care,
Ensure the roses drink the sun completely,
Chase pests away before they cause despair.

Through summer's blaze and winter's brittle chill,
Through thunderstorms that lash with silver whips,
My watchful eyes survey each leaf and frond,
My hands correct when nature slips.

For in this plot of earth I find my purpose –
Guardian of green in ordered, living rows,
Where chaos bends to human dedication,
And every bloom that comes, my vigilance bestows.

I always see to it, my child, you know,
Your nightmares flee when moonlight stains the wall.
I stand as sentry where the shadows grow
And catch each frightened whisper ere it falls.

When monsters creep from underneath your bed,
I wield a broom to sweep them clean away.
When fever burns your small and weary head,
I conjure coolness for the breaking day.

I memorize the rhythm of your breath
And count the stars until your lashes close.
Defying terror, illness, even death,
I build a fortress where your courage grows.

No dragon slips beyond my watchful gaze,
No sorrow lingers where my lullabies
Spin silver threads through restless nights and days –
For you, I armor shut the weeping skies.

The lighthouse keeper muttered to the gale,
"I always see to it the beam holds fast.
When ships approach these jagged teeth of stone,
My vigilance outwits the ocean's wrath."

Through fog that swallows stars in cotton gloom,
Through waves that howl like banshees at the door,
His lantern carves a path across the brine,
A golden road where hope may safely moor.

He scrubs the lens until it blinds the dark,
Rebuilds the gears the salt wind tries to rust.
No tempest shakes his adamantine vow:
To pierce the night with unrelenting trust.

For every sailor lost in yesteryears,
His flame burns brighter, fiercer than despair –
A small defiant sun against the fear,
An answered prayer suspended in the air.

The clockmaker squints through his magnifying glass,
"I always see to it the cogs align."
His tweezers place a ruby jewel with grace
Where tiny wheels perform their strict design.

He oils the springs that coil like sleeping snakes,
Adjusts the pendulum's hypnotic sway,
Ensures each numeral on the porcelain face
Meets golden hands precisely every day.

Through winter frost that stiffens metal joints,
Through summer heat that warps the polished oak,
His patience mends what entropy destroys,
Restoring order with each careful stroke.

For in this microcosm made of brass,
He wrestles chaos into measured rhyme –
A universe contained behind clear glass,
Where seconds bow to his relentless time.

The raven on the gnarled oak declares,
"I always see to it the secrets spread.
When lovers meet beneath my moonlit boughs,
I memorize the promises they've said.

I track the thief who prowls in velvet night,
Observe the widow placing lilies down,
Witness the gambler's dice that turn just right,
The mayor's hand that palms a golden crown.

My feathers soak the whispers of the town –
The baker's debts, the poet's stifled cries,
The soldier's letter when his head hangs down,
The truth behind the diplomat's sweet lies.

I hoard these truths like coins in hidden nooks,
But share them all when autumn winds arise –
Scattered like leaves in all my raven books,
A thousand stories gleaming in my eyes."

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

text.response:
I always see to it that each petal's dew
Glistens at dawn, a promise kept anew.
That roots drink deep where hidden streams run clear,
And tangled vines find trellises held dear.
Through summer's blaze or winter's brittle rime,
I guard the green against the theft of time.
No blossom fades without my knowing why -
I trace the sun's path in the butterfly's eye.
When storms conspire to break the slender stem,
I weave invisible nets to shelter them.
For every bud that trembles, half-unfurled,
I measure earth and sky to shape its world.
This constant vigil, quiet as moonlight,
Turns barren soil to gardens overnight.
Though no one sees the hands that trim and tend,
The roses know I'm faithful to the end.

I always see to it the clocks agree,
Each tiny gear meshing with certainty.
When midnight's chime must kiss the morning's sigh,
I calibrate the moon that swims on high.
The planets dance because I count their turns,
The wobble of the axis my concern.
I file the teeth of comets as they pass,
Pour starlight oil through galaxies of glass.
No cosmic pendulum swings out of phase -
I watch the metronome that sets our days.
Should gravity forget its steadfast pull,
My micrometer hands would mend the lull.
The universe expands inside my palm -
A silver watch escaping entropy's calm.
Precision is my covenant and creed:
I oil the hinges where the angels speed.

I always see to it the bread is warm,
Defying winter's unforgiving storm.
These hands knead solace into crusted loaves,
While guarding secrets that the oven stoves
Impart to flour rising like a prayer -
This alchemy of patience, smoke, and air.
When hunger prowls in shadows cold and deep,
I rouse the drowsy yeast from floury sleep.
No child shall weep with emptiness inside,
For dough transforms where love and craft collide.
The cinnamon recalls some sunlit grove,
Each butter swirl a testament I wove
To wrap the world in kitchens' golden rhyme -
I consecrate the sacrament of thyme.
Through famine, war, or plague's relentless sway,
My oven light declares: "There breaks a day."

I always see to it the lighthouse gleams,
Slicing through fog with razor-sharpened beams.
My vigil carved in salt and solitude,
I parse the tempest's volatile mood.
When ships mistake the rocks for lover's arms,
I hurl defiance back at crashing harms.
No captain drowns within my jurisdiction -
This whirling eye defies the dark's affliction.
I calibrate catastrophe's approach
With mathematics scribbled on night's broach.
The lens collects a hundred thousand stars
To forge a sword that sunders prison bars
Of blindness. Hear my rotating decree:
"Not here, not now, shall perish kiss the sea."
My filament heart burns through the endless freeze -
A sentinel against the ravenous breeze.

I always see to it the silence grows,
Where restless minds find respite from their woes.
In attic rooms where dusty sunbeams play,
I stack the quiet thick as gathered hay.
No frantic thought escapes my velvet snare -
I pad the walls with swallows' whispered air.
When chaos bangs its kettle-drum outside,
I spin cocoons where peace may safely hide.
The clock's loud heartbeat muffled by my palm,
Each shrill alarm transformed to liquid calm.
I harvest stillness from the moon's cool stream
To drown the sirens of the frantic dream.
Behold: this sanctuary built of hush
Where even shadows move without a rush.
The world may shriek beyond my guarded door -
Within, a thousand tranquil pulses pour.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

text.response:
I always see to it that dawn arrives on time,
Unfurling gold across the sleeping earth,
My fingers trace the frost on windowpanes,
And coax the stubborn seeds to crack their berth.
I count the petals on the trembling rose,
Adjust the tilt of every fledgling's wing,

I smooth the wrinkles from the twilight's gown,

I always see to it the teapot sings

The quilt gets tucked around forgotten things,

Your footsteps echo in the empty hall—
I polish silence till it gleams like glass,
Rearrange the dust motes when they fall,
And time the pendulum before you pass.
The photograph that leans against the shelf?
I nudge it straight each time your eyes grow dim.
The letters from the war I guard myself,
Though ink bleeds through the folder's brittle rim.
This vigil keeps your loneliness at bay:
A ghost who mends what living hands decay.

I always see to it the forest breathes—
Direct the roots to sip the hidden streams,
Command the vines to weave their verdant wreaths,
Translate the wind’s unspoken, ancient themes.
When beetles gnaw the bark in moonlit hours,
I summon ants to march in gleaming rows.
I calibrate the scent of midnight flowers,
And orchestrate the thunder’s fierce crescendo.
No leaf may fall without my sharp decree,
No spider spins her web without my chart.
The seasons turn because they answer me—
Each frost, each bloom, a masterpiece of art.
This wild dominion bends beneath my stare:
Creation’s chaos shaped with tender care.

I always see to it the bread knife rests
Precisely where your fingers crave its weight.
Your coffee cools exactly to the warmth
That lingers in the hollow of your plate.
The crossword’s clues align with morning light,
The radio hums your forgotten tune,
The soap dissolves the residue of night,
And mirrors show no cracks before high noon.
Each shoelace knot I test for hidden flaws,
Each sock’s rebellion smoothed before you rise.
I memorize the gaps between your pause,
The fleeting shadows haunting downcast eyes.
This unseen choreography I weave—
The keeper of the patterns you believe.

I always see to it the borders hold—
Where desert bleeds into the cobalt sea,
Where glaciers fracture secrets long untold,
Where tectonic plates groan restlessly.
I chart the magma’s subterranean course,
Command the tides to kneel before the shore,
Correct the planets when they drift off course,
And lock tectonic doors forevermore.
No avalanche escapes my stern command,
No hurricane forgets my measured wrath.
The continents shift at my gestured hand,
The polar ice retreats along my path.
This fragile sphere spins true beneath my gaze—
Cosmic mechanic through unending days.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

text.response:
I always see to it that the moon has company,
That stars aren't lonely in their velvet bed,
I polish constellations carefully
And stitch new dreams where old ones went to tread.
When autumn leaves begin to blush and fade,
I brew the colors in my copper pot,
Stir crimson into sunset's grand parade
To warm the chill that wintertime forgot.
I mend the spider's lace at break of day,
Replenish dew in every waiting cup,
Direct the sunbeams where the shadows play,
And coax reluctant butterflies up.
This cosmic choreography I keep -
The world's small heartbeats in my palm asleep.

I always see to it the kettle sings
Before your eyelids greet the morning gray,
That honey swirls in golden, liquid rings
To sweeten hours before you go away.
I count the buttons marching down your coat,
Replace the missing thread before it shows,
Plant courage in your pocket like a note
To bloom when hesitation grows.
Your umbrella waits beside the door each storm,
Your favorite chair remembers how you lean,
I smooth the edges when the world turns warm
And guard the spaces in between.
These silent currencies of daily care
Are love translated into touch and air.

The garden knows I always see to it:
That greedy weeds don't choke the peony's pride,
That midnight slugs cannot commit
Their silver crimes where tender roots reside.
I bargain with the sun for extra hours,
Negotiate with rain for gentle spills,
Employ the strength of stems like watchtowers,
Prescribe sweet soil as tonic for the ills.
When frost arrives with icy, creeping breath,
I swaddle roots in blankets made of hay,
Outwit the winter plotting green's beheading,
Until spring's truce arrives one fragile day.
This vegetal diplomacy I wage -
Life's fragile contract signed on every page.

I always see to it the clocks behave,
That minutes don't collapse like dominoes,
I oil the grinding gears that daylight crave
And mend the cracks where hurried chaos grows.
I fold the corners of the universe
So time won't fray at edges growing thin,
Tuck seconds into pockets to disperse
When someone needs to catch the breath within.
The pendulum's confession I record,
Correct the stutters in the twilight's chime,
Adjust the tempo with a whispered word
To synchronize with every heartbeat's rhyme.
This horologist of cosmic schemes
Weaves temporal threads into eternal dreams.

The stray cats know I always see to it:
That cardboard palaces withstand the rain,
That tuna cans with punctured tops submit
Their treasures to the colony's domain.
I mediate the sparrow-cat debates,
Apportion sunbeams on the concrete stair,
Translate the language at the garden gates
Where whiskered diplomats declare their care.
When winter bites with needle-sharpened fangs,
I build igloos from discarded foam,
Prescribe warm milk for melancholic pangs
And map safe passage for each journey home.
This feline United Nations I sustain -
Small lives made mighty by my watchful reign.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

text.response:
I always see to it that the dawn finds its way,
Through curtains of night, to bring forth the day.
The petals unfurl when the spring whispers low,
The river keeps flowing wherever it goes.
I tend to the embers when hearths grow cold,
Guard stories untold in books growing old.
When shadows grow long and doubt starts to creep,
I promise the stars their secrets I'll keep.
For fledglings that falter mid-first anxious flight,
I steady the breeze till their wings catch the light.
And should your heart falter, weighed down by the gray,
I'll polish your courage like sun after rain.
This vigil I keep – no trumpet, no drum –
Just making quite certain the good things will come.

I always see to it – the clocks know my tread,
Their hands never waver, no second misled.
I oil hidden gears in the depths of the night,
Keep pendulum swinging with delicate might.
When frost tries to silence the grandfather's chime,
I breathe warmth upon it, restoring its time.
No cog is forgotten, no spring left to chance,
Invisible keeper of life's steady dance.
The metronome's tick and the wristwatch's glow,
The sundial's shadow – all trust me to know
That order persists where chaos might reign.
My hands, ever busy, defy the entropy's claim.
A whisper of purpose in tick-tocking halls:
I see to the rhythm that governs us all.

I always see to it the ink doesn't fade
On letters you sent from that seaside arcade.
The sand in the hourglass? I count every grain.
The pressed maple leaf in your journal remains.
When memory flickers like candles half-spent,
I shield the bright wick where your laughter is kept.
I catalogue fireflies in midsummer jars,
Preserve the exact pitch of rain on old cars.
Your childhood blanket, though threadbare and thin?
I guard every fiber that cradled your skin.
Forgetting’s a thief I’ve sworn to outwit.
No fragment of sweetness escapes while I sit
This vigil of details, both fragile and grand –
The archivist of moments slipped through your hand.

I always see to it the wreckage is neat
When chaos erupts in the bustling street.
The shattered glass sparkles? I sweep it with care.
The fallen bird's nest? I weave it with prayer.
After arguments shatter like porcelain plates,
I gather the shards before bitterness waits.
I mute the alarms, reset tripped circuits alone,
Turn down the sirens' hysterical drone.
When tempests rage furious, wild and unbound,
I anchor the rooftiles deep in the ground.
No aftermath lingers too sharp or too raw –
I smooth the torn edges with invisible claw.
The world may erupt, but I stand in the breach

I always see to it the borders stay drawn

The woods may be lovely, but shadows hold teeth –

I double-check latches when nightmares draw near,

No shortcut's untested, no promise assumed,

I catalog exits in theatres aflame,
